. I am a constable - I received him in charge, and on his person found a screwdriver, a bag, a large knife, and two small screws - here is the mat; the string it is sewn with is cut.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. When the woman came out I was twenty yards from the door; she said, "You wretch, what have you been doing?" I said I had done no harm, and went round the corner; the gentleman laid hold of me - I have been out of employ a long time, and many days have not broken my fast for nine hours.

GUILTY . Aged 33. -
Transported for Seven Years .

592.
JOHN HARDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of January , 12 ozs. of copper, value 6d.; 3 weights, value 1s. 6d., and 17 copper coins, value 3d., the goods of
John Warner
and another, his masters .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

HENRY MILWARD
. I am in the employ of John and
Robert Warner
, brass-founder s, Jewin-crescent
- the prisoner was in their employ. On the 17th of January, in consequence of directions, I watched him, and about a quarter-past twelve o'clock I saw him take the copper out of the pan and put it into his pocket - it was old halfpence and pocket-pieces intended for melting; I told Mr. Handley.

JAMES WILLIAM HANDLEY
. I am foreman to Messrs. Warner. In consequence of what Milward said, I fetched the prisoner from the foundry into the counting-house, and told him he had something in his possession which did not belong to him - he said he had not; I said he had - he pulled out two halfpence; I said, "That will not do, I must have the rest" - he then pulled out 12 ozs. of small copper, said it was the first time, and he hoped I would let him go; I went with the officer to his lodging, and found a 1 lb., a 2 lbs., and a - lb. weight, and a piece of copper, which are masters'.
Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. Is it unusual for men when melting to put money into their pockets? A. No, it is never allowed.

JOHN ANDREWS
. I produce the copper, which was delivered to me.

JAMES WILLIAM HANDLEY
. This is the copper I delivered to the constable - we have a hundred and forty men in our employ.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you hold out any threat or promise to him? A. None at all - he has a wife and six children; I believe master had a fifteen years' character with him.
JURY. Q. What did he earn a week? A. For the last twelve weeks he has earned 30s. a week.
GUILTY. Aged 35.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Two Months .

593.
HENRY KILLMINSTER
was
indicted for a misdemeanor .
MR. ELLIS conducted the prosecution.

JOSHUA GRIFFITH. I am servant to
John Drake
, who keeps a coal-shed , No. 7, Lambeth-hill
. On the 21st of January , about five o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came for 2d. worth of fire-wood - it was dark; he offered me a half-crown, which I took, and gave him 2s. 4d. change - he went away; I took the half-crown in to mistress, left it with her, and in about a quarter of an hour I saw him on Lambeth-hill, in Collier's custody - my master said to me in his hearing, "Is this the man who gave you the half-crown?" I said Yes, it was - he said he had never been near our shop; I am certain he is the man.

MARY ANN DRAKE
. I am the wife of John Drake. On the 21st of January, about five o'clock, I received a half-crown from Griffith - I had received no other that evening; I remarked in a minute or two that it was very had, and put it into a corner of the desk on a book - there was no other half-crown near it; I was particular in keepit by itself - in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour Masters came to change a half-crown; I thought it looked like the one I had from Griffith - I called my husband, who went away with her, and in five or ten minutes Collier brought the prisoner in; I gave him the same half-crown as I had from Griffith - I took it off the book where I had put it; I can swear it is the same.

HANNAH MASTERS
. My husband is in the Guards, and I keep a green-shop at No. 25, Lambeth-hill. On the 21st of January, at a quarter-past five o'clock, the prisoner was outside my window - I was in my room; he said, "Halloo, mistress;" I went out to him, but in the mean time two other men passed, and he said to them, "Two or three?" they said, "Get three;" they went on, and he stopped, put his hand on a savoy, and asked the price - I said 1 1/2d. - he only asked for one; I served him - he had 3 lbs. of potatoes for 2d., which made 3 1/2d.; he gave me half a crown, which I could not change, and went two doors below, to Mrs. Buckle's - she weighed the half-crown, and it was light - it never went out of my sight; I then went to Drake's, and in consequence of what passed there, she called her husband, and the prisoner was apprehended by Collier, to whom I gave the half-crown, but cut a piece out of it before I parted with it; Griffith said, in his hearing, that he had given him a half-crown - the prisoner said he had not been near his shop.

JOSEPH COLLIER
. I apprehended the prisoner about five o'clock that day, waiting at Masters' door for his change; I took him into Drake's parlour, and searched him, but found no money on him - he had three bundles of wood in his apron; I received this half-crown from Masters, and another from Drake.

JOHN FIELD
. I am inspecter of counterfeit coin for the Mint. Both these half-crowns are counterfeit - they are made of Britannia metal, and appear cast from the samemould; the metal is much lighter than silver - the coin of the Realm is struck with a die.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that a man named Clark had met him, and sent him with the money, which he did not know was counterfeit.
GUILTY .

Confined Six Months , and
to find Sureties .

594.
WILLIAM FERGUSSON
was
indicted for a misdemeanor .

THOMAS BEVAN
. I am a surgeon , and live in Queen-street, Cheapside
. I know Job Grimshaw, of Staples Inn-buildings, a bookbinder - I cannot identify the prisoner's person; but this paper was brought to me, and I delivered to the person who brought it, three sovereigns, for Mr. Grimshaw, on the 27th of December , believing that the paper came from Grimshaw, who had bound books for me-I saw the prisoner at the Mansion-house about three weeks after, charged with this offence - (paper read.)
27th of December, 1830.
SIR, - I take the liberty of writing to you to ask the favor of the loan of 3l. for a few days; if you can oblige I shall be glad.
Yours, J. GRIMSHAW.

JOB GRIMSHAW
. I live at No. 6, Staples Inn-buildings, and am acquainted with
Thomas Bevan
. The prisoner was in my service about nine months, and had left about eighteen months when this occurred; I believe while he was with me I sent him to Mr. Bevan's on business - I did not send him on the 27th of December, or any body, to request the loan of 3l. from Mr. Bevan; this paper is not written by me, nor by my authority - the prisoner never brought me the 3l.; I did not know he was going on such an errand.

HENRY CLEMENTS
. I am assistant to Messrs. Hooper and Bevan, of Queen-street. On the 27th of December I recollect the prisoner calling on Mr. Bevan with a note - it was not sealed, and I opened it; it requested the loan of 3l.; when Mr. Bevan came in he read it, went up stairs, and brought the prisoner down a small brown paper parcel - I am certain of his person, but not positive of the date; it was about that time - I saw him in custody at the Mansion-house about three weeks after, and was quite certain of him.
JURY. Q. Did you ask the boy where he came from? A. The moment he brought it he said he came from Job Grimshaw, and it requested an answer; he did not say where Grimshaw lived.
MR. BEVAN. I gave him the sovereigns in brown paper.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .
NEW COURT. TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22.
Third Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

595.
BENJAMIN MILLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of January , 1 cloak, value 5s. , the goods of
Joseph Markham
.

JOSEPH MARKHAM
. I live in Williams'-mews, Hampstead-road, and am driver of the cab , No. 194. On the 18th of January I went into a chemist's-shop, No. 260, Tottenham-court-road
, and left my cab at the door, with a cloak on the seat; I saw the prisoner pass, and take the cloak - I ran out; he turned into Russell-street, and threw it down - I took it up, and followed him; I lost sight of him for about a minute; when I saw him again he was still running - I have no doubt that he is the man; I took him - the Police-constable came and took him; he said he was very sorry for it.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Was any body with you when he made this statement? A. The Policeman was; it was not a very dark night - it was between ten and eleven o'clock; he was taken within one hundred yards of the spot.

JOSEPH STANNARD
. I am a Police-constable. I heard a cry of Stop thief! I ran, saw the prisoner running very fast, and a number of people after him, up Russell-street, Tavistock-street, and round into Tottenham-court-road - he told me he had had no victuals the whole of the day, and he would starve before he would do any thing of the kind again.
Cross-examined. Q. He seemed very contrite? A. Yes - he was quite cut up about it.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined One Month .

596.
HENRY JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 pair of trousers, value 7s. , the goods of
Jonas Benjamin
.

MICHAEL GABRIEL
. I live in Homer-street, Marylebone
, and am a dealer in clothes. I was at my door between ten and eleven o'clock on the 16th of February, and saw the prisoner handling some trousers at
Jonas Benjamin
's window - I thought he handled them rather longer than he ought, and I saw him unloop a pair, put them under his arm, and walk down the street: I followed, and as he turned the corner of Crawford-street, I tapped him on the shoulder - I took him back; a mob gathered round - he endeavored to get away, but I gave him in charge.

THOMAS HENRY THOMPSON
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner outside Mr. Benjamin's shop: I asked how he came in possession of the trousers - he said he had picked them up.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going down the street, and there were several Jews going by, with loads of clothes - I saw the trousers on the pavement; I took them up, and walked quietly down the street - the witness said he would keep me; a number of people came up, said he was no officer, and had no right to hold me, so I tried to put his hands off.

JURY to
MICHAEL GABRIEL
. Q. Did he bring the same trousers back which you saw him take from the shop? A. Yes, these are them - they have the mark on them.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined Six Months .

597.
JOSEPH CARMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of January , 1 cap, value 4s., the goods of
William Reynolds
, the elder, from the person of
William Reynolds
, the younger; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

WILLIAM REYNOLDS
, JUN. I am the son of
William Reynolds
- he lives in Freeman's-street, Spital fields, and is a shoemaker . On Monday, the 24th of January, I was sent on an errand to Long-alley - I had to pass through Dorset-street
; I saw the prisoner and some other boy s there; the prisoner came up to my side, snatched my cap off, and gave it to his companions - they then ran away, towardsFrench-alley; the other boys called the prisoner Joe - I was sent for to the Police-station on the Friday night, where I saw the prisoner, and knew him; I am quite clear he is the person who took my cap - I had seen him before; it was a new seal skin cap.

JAMES WALTON
. I am a Police-constable. I received information, and looked for the prisoner, and on the Friday night I met him in White Lion-street, at half-past eight o'clock, with three or four other boys; he saw me, and ran towards Shoreditch - I went up to the corner of White Lion-street, and he was peeping round the corner; he then ran down Shoreditch - I pursued, and took him into custody; he said, "What do you want me for?" I said for a boy's cap which he had stolen on the Monday - he said, "Let me go home to my mother," but I took him to the station.

SARAH REYNOLDS
. I am the wife of
William Reynolds
. On this night my son had a new seal skin cap on, which I gave 4s. 6d. for - the next morning, when I was going to send him out, he said he had lost it, but he should get it back again, as he knew the boy.
Prisoner's Defence. I can only say I know nothing of the cap.

THOMAS COTTERELL
. I am a Police-constable. I produce a certificate of a former conviction of the prisoner in May last - I attended, and know he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 12. -
Transported for Life .

597.
MARY STEVENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of January , 1 watch, value 30s., the goods of
Thomas Martin
, from his person .

THOMAS MARTIN. I live at Little Stanmore, and was a farmer , but the lease of the land is out. I went to the Red Lion public-house, at Paddington
, about seven o'clock, and stopped till a little after eight; I saw the prisoner there - I was not so much in liquor but that I knew what I was about; I am quite clear I saw the prisoner, and I think she had a glass of gin at my expence, but whether she drank it or not I do not know - I saw two other women there; I did not get more intoxicated - I went from there to the Key in Bell-square; after a while the prisoner came in - I was then going from there to a man's house, whom I wanted to see; the prisoner followed me, and snatched my watch out of my pocket - I do not know the name of the street; it is at the lower end of Bell-street
- when she caught the watch out of my fob I was knocked down by three or four persons, and who had the watch I cannot tell, but I am clear the prisoner took it; it was not light - I could not tell the men, but there were three or four of them; I suppose it might be nine o'clock - I do not think there were any lamps - not to give much light there; but I know the prisoner - she followed me out of the Key, but she was a distance behind; I did not see her follow me, but I know her person - I have seen her many scores of times, for years past at Paddington; upon my oath she is the person who took my watch - I lost my purse and all my money, which was torn out of my pocket.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You are quite sure she is the person who took your watch? A. Yes; I was picked up by the Policeman - she was taken the next day; I swear I told the Policeman who picked me up, that it was the prisoner, but I did not know her name - I was not so drunk when I went to the Red Lion but that I could do any business, and I knew what I was about; I did not sit down there - I had drank at several different places where I had called; most likely I had had some gin - I might have had rum, but no brandy; that is a liquor I seldom drink - I cannot tell how many public-houses I had been in; I should think I had not been in half a dozen, but I could not swear to a thing like that, or to what I had there - I had no beer at the Red Lion to my recollection; I was not in there five minutes - very likely somebody might give me some beer; I cannot say whether I had three several quarterns of gin at the Red Lion, or what I had - the place was full of people all the time; I did not go away from the Red Lion with the prisoner that I know of - I never saw her go out; I went away by myself, and went to the Key; I wanted to find a man there -I cannot say whether I had treated the prisoner at the Red Lion; I and another man were tossing up, and whether she had any gin or not I cannot say - I cannot tell what I drank at the Key; I think it was gin - I do not think I had more than a glass; I had no wine there - I had none to my knowledge; I cannot swear what I drank in the course of the day - I did not go away with the prisoner from the Key; I know the prisoner came in there - I think I lost my watch about nine o'clock; it was past seven before I went to the Red Lion: I did not state the next morning that I was so drunk I could not tell whether the prisoner was the person or not - I always said it was her; I had no other persons taken up but her; there were two men taken, but I did not take them - there were three or four men in the crowd.

WILLIAM ELLIOTT
. I am a Police-constable. From information I received I went to Burn-street, Lisson-grove, on Monday, the 17th of January, the night the robbery was said to have happened - I found the prisoner about half-past eleven o'clock, sitting in a room before the fire, on the floor; she was nearly naked - there were two men sitting one on each side of the fire; I went up to one of the men named King, who was sitting with his head down, apparently asleep - I put my hand on his head, and he looked up in my face - I said, "Where is the watch?" he said,"What watch, master?" I said, "The old man's watch;" he said, "I know nothing about it;" I said, "Then I shall take you all into custody;" the prisoner said, "Then, so help me - , if you do you will take the wrong;" a great many angry words passed, saying they would not go - the prisoner then turned to the other man, named Collins; she put her hand on his knee, and said, "Never mind Jem, I will cut this bl-y throat of mine before I will split," and he answered, "Never mind Poll, they shall, or I will, put a rope round this bl-y neck of mine before I will split;" we were obliged to get the assistance of four more constables, before we could get them away - I took them all to the station, and as we were going, I heard the prisoner say to a Mr. Hainsworth, "Never mind, you may say what you like, I know I shall get lagged."
Cross-examined. Q. Did she appear to have been drinking? A. She had been drinking.

Prisoner's Defence. I was half naked - I had a blue striped gown on, which I could not get off without taking it over my shoulders; I objected going - I told him if hewould bring the person who had lost his watch, I would go quietly; a person came to me from a person who used to cohabit with Hainsworth, saying that she knew who had the watch, and I sent a note to the governor about it.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Life .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

598.
WILLIAM ROBROUGH GORNALL
was
indicted for bigamy .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

OCTAVIUS YOUNG THISELTON
. I am parish-clerk of St. Pancras. I have the register of marriages in that church. On the 17th of July, 1823,
William Gornall
and
Eleanor Elizabeth Prince
were married there.

ISAAC KIMPTON
. I am an officer of St. Pancras. I know a woman who applied for relief, in the name of Mrs. Gornall, two or three months ago - I saw the prisoner with her; she got a warrant against him, and he was taken into custody - she claimed in his presence to be his wife; he said he was very sorry for what had happened - he acknowledged she was his wife.
Q. Did he deny that she was his wife in any way? A. No.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Did he never state to you, that there was another William Gornall, a cousin of his, who was a mariner? A. Never, I am quite sure; I saw the prisoner and the woman I called his wife together, in Britannia-street, when I apprehended them - this conversation took place in the street, in going to Hatton-garden Office.
COURT. Q. Did both the wives claim relief from the parish? A. No, the first only.

HARRY PRICE
. I am overseer of St. Pancras. A woman claiming to be the wife of the prisoner, applied for relief - I gave orders for a warrant to be issued against the prisoner; he was brought to the vestry-room - I saw him there with Isaac Kimpton; I said I thought it was a great pity the parish should be burdened with his family - he said he had allowed her 10s. a week for some time, but was unable to do so then; I said he must go before the Magistrate, which he did - his wife was there and identified him as her husband; the Magistrate remanded him -I applied to the parish-clerk of All Souls, Marylebone, and got a certificate of the register, which I here produce; I examined it, and it is correct. - (read)

"In the district rectory of All Souls, Marylebone
,
William Robrough Gornall
, batchelor, and
Hannah Palmer
, spinster , were married by banns, on the 4th of October, 1829 , by me, H. Nathan, curate, in the presence of
Jane Watkins
and
William Watkins
."

Cross-examined. Q. Are you not confounding
Hannah Palmer
with the other wife? A. No - they were both present at the two examinations, but I am speaking of the first time; he was then speaking of his wife, not of
Hannah Palmer
- he certainly did not speak about
Hannah Palmer
when he spoke of his wife; he did not tell me that
Eleanor Elizabeth
was the wife of a cousin of his, who was a mariner at sea, and that he had allowed her 10s. a week for him.

HANNAH PALMER
. I married the prisoner at All Souls, Marylebone, on the 4th of October, 1829.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had cohabited with the woman supposed to be his first wife, but that she was the wife of
William Gornall
, who was now at sea; and that he had done his best to maintain both her and Palmer He received a good character.

HANNAH PALMER
re-examined. Q. Whose child is that in your arms? A. The prisoner's - I had been living at home with my father, before I married him; he never represented that he was married, and I never suspected it - he was an excellent husband to me, and a good father.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Four Months .

599.
JANE ROGERS
was
indicted for bigamy .
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

HENRY FOLKES. I produce a certificate of the marriage of
Jane Nowell
and
James Rogers
, at St. Ann's, Westminster, on the 26th of May, in the 42nd year of the reign of George the Third.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Where did you get it? A. From Mr. Sawyer; I saw the register, and can take upon me to say that this is a literal transcript of it.

WILLIAM NORTON
. I am a chair-maker, and live at No. 11, Carnaby-street. I knew the prisoner in 1802, and before that; she was then single - I was invited to go to her wedding, in that year, but I could not go - she was to be married to a person of the name of Rogers; I had known him before - I think the wedding was about May; her master gave an entertainment, but I was not there - I think I saw
James Rogers
the next day, but the prisoner was not there; Rogers is alive, and is outside the door - he allowed her ten shillings a week, for some time, and I stopped the payment of it; her name was
Jane Nowell
before her marriage - she afterwards went by the name of Rogers.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know her before? A. Yes, by coming to see her sister - I was invited to the wedding by her brother-in-law, who gave her away; I do not know that she is out of her mind - I am told her husband has paid for her, as a lunatic pauper, in the parish of Clerkenwell; I had known Rogers perhaps two years before - I did not know that he had been married before.

JOHN HUNTER MARLER
. I married the woman at the bar, on the 31st of March, 1807 .

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know Rogers? A. No; I have paid eight shillings a week for the prisoner, for about two years - I did send her to a mad-house, but I was with her for fourteen or fifteen years, till I became in danger of my life. and I was advised to part with her; she has been living as a lunatic pauper in Clerkenwell.

GUILTY . Aged 49. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

600.
FREDERICK SCAMMELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of January
, 7 boxes, value 7s. , the goods of
James Tilt
; and
JOHN SHEPHERD
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.

MARY REEVE
. I have lately been nursing in the family of Mr.
James Tilt
, a tobacconist . On the 19th of January, fifteen or sixteen snuff-boxes were taken from his window; they could be taken by a person without coming into the shop.

THOMAS NISBETT
. I live with my father and mother,in Ravenhill's-rents, near Leather-lane. About the middle of last month, I saw the two prisoners together in Leather-lane
, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening; I had known them before - I saw Scammell sell some boxes to Shepherd; they were in Scammell's hand when I first saw them - he sold them to Shepherd; I believe I saw five of them - I believe Shepherd said he would give 9d. for them, but I saw no money pass; I did not see any shilling, nor heard any thing about change for a shilling - no one has been talking to me lately about this; I told my mother that I saw Shepherd buy the boxes; I did not see him put them into his apron.

WILLIAM ATTRIDGE
. I am a Police-constable. I received information from Nisbett that he had seen some boxes pass between the prisoners; I took Scammell first, and asked him what he had done with the boxes which he had - he said he had had no boxes; I mentioned about some being taken from a tobacconist's in Gray's Inn-lane - he still denied it; I then said he had sold some to Shepherd - he said he had sold him five for 9d.: I sent for Shepherd, who denied having any, but when I told him Scammell had acknowledged he had sold him some, he said he had bought five of him; he then took me to a house, and gave me five, and when I got him to the station he told me there were two more at his house - I went there and got them; he sells greens and other articles about the streets.
Shepherd. Q. Did you ever see me do any thing wrong, or idle my time? A. No.

JAMES TILT. These are my boxes. I put eighteen boxes on one side of my window that morning, and eighteen on the other; I lost fifteen of them in the evening - a piece of glass was broken out of my window; it had been mended, but the piece was quite firm in - these are worth seven shillings.
Scammell's Defence. Shepherd bought them not knowing them to be stolen; I told him I had found them.
Shepherd's Defence. I bought them, but I declare I never knew they were stolen.

SCAMMELL -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .

SHEPHERD -
NOT GUILTY .

601.
JAMES VALENTINE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of February , 3 lbs. of pork, value 2s. , the goods of
Edward Boniface
.

EDWARD BONIFACE
. I am a cheesemonger . I missed a piece of pork from my board in my shop-window, on the 5th of February; I ran out, and saw the prisoner about thirty yards from my shop - he ran; I pursued him - he threw the pork down, but he was pursued and taken - the pork was taken up and brought to me; I missed such a piece, and have no doubt it was mine.
The prisoner received a good character, and a gentleman stated he would take him into his employ.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

602.
ANN WILLIAMS
and
ELLEN HOLLAND
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of February , 2 sheets, value 1s. 3d., and 1 quilt, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Philip Ward
.

KEZIAH WARD
. I am the wife of
William Ward
; we live at No. 9, New-way, Westminster
. On the 4th of February Williams came to my house alone, and wanted a room for herself and another young woman; she said they got their bread by needle-work - I took her up stairs, and showed her the second floor front-room which was furnished; she took it and gave me a shilling earnest - they were to give 4s. a week for it; they took the room immediately, but I did not see Holland till I went up stairs at night to give them a pair of sheets and a counterpane - they were then in the room; they continued to live there till the 9th of February; when I went up and knocked at the door they asked who was there - I said the landlady, and I wanted to come in for something particular; they said they were cleaning themselves, but if I would go down stairs they would call me when they were ready - I stood on the landing-place; when the door was opened I looked in and missed the bed, and saw the room was stripped of nearly every thing but the table and a tea-kettle - they got down stairs; I called out, but nobody could get out of their rooms in time to prevent them - they got into the street; we called the Policeman - they were pursued and taken; I missed the saucepain, pail, fire-shovel, and a variety of other things.

THOMAS COX
. I am in the service of Mr. Ravenhill, a pawnbroker. I have two sheets; one pawned on the 5th, and the other on the 7th of February, by one of the prisoners, but I cannot call to recollection which, though I know their faces - the articles are both in the name of
Mary Williams
, but with two different directions.

WILLIAM MUGGERIDGE
. I am in the service of Mr. Harris, a pawnbroker. I have a quilt, pawned by Williams, in the name of Ann Holland, on the 7th of February.
Williams. It was not me; I sent it - I had not a gown to go out in. Witness. I am quite certain it was her.

JOHN BENTON
. I am a Police-constable. I was at the apprehension of both these girls; when they were in the watch-house I went to the room they had lived in, and found in a box these two duplicates of the sheets - when they were before the Magistrate they voluntarily said they had pawned them to get bread.

THOMAS COX
. These are the duplicates I gave them.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoners put in a paper, stating that they were in a very destitute condition, and that the prosecutrix kept a house of ill fame.

WILLIAM -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

HOLLAND -
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

603.
EDWARD HERBERT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February
, 1 cap, value 5s., the goods of
Joseph Jarrett
, from the person of
Frederick Jarrett
; and
EDWARD GILES
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen .

JOSEPH JARRETT
. I am eleven years old, and live with my father and mother at Chelsea. On the 13th of February I was in my father's bed-room, and saw my little brother Frederick run round the house into College-place
; he had his cap on then; the two prisoners followed him -I saw Herbert take the cap off his head, give it to Giles, and they both ran off together down John-street; I went and told my father - he told the Police-constable; they were taken about eleven o'clock at night - I know theyare the same persons; I observed them for a quarter of an hour at the window - the cap has never been found.

FREDERICK JARRETT
. I am eight years old. I went out; Herbert took my cap off, and gave it to the other -I am sure they are the men; I have not found the cap.

JOSEPH JARRETT
. I am the father of these two boy s. I did not see the prisoners near my house; my sons described them, and recognized them the same night.

GEORGE CASLEY
. I am an officer. The mother of these lads described the prisoners to me: I took Herbert at the corner of Manor-street, King's-road - he behaved very well; I took Giles in the Lord Nelson public-house, a little before ten o'clock - I have not been able to find the cap; Herbert bears an excellent character from his late master.

COURT to
JOSEPH JARRETT
. Q. At the time your brother's cap was taken off by Herbert, was Giles close to him? A. Yes.

HERBERT -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

GILES -
NOT GUILTY .

604.
SAMUEL MEDLEY
was indicted for
embezzling 3 sums of 4 1/2d. each, the monies of
William Wood
, his master .

It being the property of
Sarah Wood
, and not William Wood, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

605.
JOHN ATTERBURY
was
indicted for embezzlement .

ROBERT COX
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Tothill-street, Westminster
. The prisoner came into my employ on the 9th of December, as a porter , and to serve behind the counter occasionally - he was employed to receive monies for me; he had conducted himself with property.

GEORGE DENHAM
. I am in the prosecutor's service. On the 12th of February I saw the prisoner take a half-crown from a customer; he stooped down, and put it into his boot - I was in the shop to watch him; I had seen him do this twice in the course of the evening - I think the customer bought 2 lbs. of one shilling butter; he gave 6d. out of the till - his boot was examined; three half-half-crowns were found on him there, and one at the watch-house - he said he did not know he had any money there.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Where were you? A. At the head of the counter - I do not remember what customer it was; I can swear they bought butter, and I believe it was about 2 lbs.; he only said he did not know there was any thing in his boot - he did not say that if there was it must have got through a hole in his trousers - he said so after his examination - I did not observe whether his trousers came over his boots, but they were laced boots, and came up three or four inches.

DANIEL REARDON
. On the night stated Mr. Cox called me in: I went into the parlour behind the shop, and found the prisoner - I searched him, and found three half-crowns in a pocket on the side of his waistcoat - he said, "They are my own; I did not take them, Mr. Cox;" I took him to the office, and in the back room I said to him, "Have you any more about you?" he said No; I said, "Pull off your boots" - he pulled off one very gently, and said, "You see there is nothing there;" I took it, and found another half-crown in the toe of it - he then said they had fallen from the till.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Three Months .

606.
JAMES WILLIAM HAMPTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February , 3 Venetian blinds, value 10s. , the goods of
William Smith
.

WILLIAM JAMES WILSON
. I am a blind-maker, in the employ of Mr.
William Smith
. On the 15th of February I saw the prisoner going off his steps with these blinds; he went a few paces, and was delivering them to another person - I went out, and took him; the other ran off.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am a blind-maker . These are my blinds.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Three Months .

607.
MARY HALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of January , 1 bonnet, value 15s., and 1 cloak, value 15s. , the goods of
Ann Bradley
.

ANN BRADLEY
. I am a servant , at No. 23, Grosvenor-cottages
. On the 9th of January I was out of a situation, and lodged in the same room with the prisoner - about six o'clock that evening I lost my bonnet and cloak from the room; the bonnet was found on the prisoner's head; the cloak I have not seen - the prisoner went away without notice, and she was taken on the 22nd of January.

DANIEL REEDON
. I am a labourer. I slept in another bed in the same room - I saw the prisoner go out with the cloak and bonnet on; I laid on the bed, and she went out - I did not know whose they were them.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you know she had lent me them? A. No.

CHARLES MAYHEW
. I am an officer. I took the priprisoner on the 22nd of January, in St. Giles'; I had information that she had stolen these things about a week before - I took her to where she had lodged, and the occupier of the house said it was the prosecutor's bonnet; the prisoner said she was going to return it - I asked what she had done with the cloak, and she gave me no answer.

ANN BRADLEY. This is my bonnet - it was a dark brown cloth cloak, for which I gave a guinea; I never permitted her to take and wear my things - she was a stranger; I paid her lodging - I do not know what her trade is.
Prisoner. Yes you know very well I am an unfortunate girl, and have supported you and your child; have you not lent me that shawl you now have on? Witness. Yes, I did one night.

Prisoner's Defence. She lent me that shawl about six o'clock in the evening, and said she was distressed for clothes - I brought her in some money; she said, "As it is cold take my cloak and bonnet;" I was taken up that night, and had fourteen days in the House of Correction -I was taken by this officer the day I came out.

CHARLES MAYHEW
. She told me the reason she had not returned the bonnet was, because she had been taken into custody.
NOT GUILTY .

608.
ELIZABETH TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of February , 10 lbs. of pork, value 3s. , the goods of
Benjamin Hands
.

MARY WILDING
. I live with Mr.
Benjamin Hands
, a surgeon , near Crouch-end, Hornsey
. On the 9th of February, about half-past twelve o'clock, we lost part of a dressed loin and a leg of pork, from the safe, which is attached to the house, in the garden - I told my master, and he went to the gate; I saw the pork again in about ten minutes - I have seen the prisoner come as far as the kitchen door to offer matches for sale; this is the leg of pork, which was not dressed.

JOHN THOMAS DAWRENCE
. I was at the prosecutor's. I ran out, and saw this girl with the pork in a basket, which was her own, about a hundred yards from the gate.

GUILTY. Aged 12. -
Judgment Respited
.

609.
MARY McLEAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of January , 4 yards of carpet, value 10s. , the goods of
Jessaint McCall Knapp
and
Frederick Augustus Knapp
.

JOHN BAGULEY
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Oxford-street. On the 15th of January, about ten o'clock in the evening. the prisoner offered this piece of carpet to pledge, and stated it was the property of a person in Wardour-street - I suspected her from her rude behaviour, and sent for an officer.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Are you quite sure it was on the 15th of January? A. It was on a Saturday evening, the 15th of January.

JESSAINT McCALL KNAPP. I am in partnership with my brother
Frederick August
us Knapp; we are upholsterer
s. The prisoner first came to work at our place in September, and she has worked there almost continually ever since - she received her wages between six and seven o'clock on the 15th of January, but she was not discharged; I expected her to return on Monday: this is our carpet - there are four yards of it; it is worth 14s. - I did not permit her to take it away.

Cross-examined. Q. She was not regularly employed by you? A. She was almost - I paid her her wages in the parlour on the Saturday night - I did not see her leave the house; I had seen this carpet in the course of that week -I cannot say what day; we had more of this pattern in the house, and some of it had been sold - I will not say positively when I had seen this piece; I did not miss it till the Tuesday, when I received information.

GUILTY. Aged 24. -
Judgment Respited
.

610.
LEONARD JAMES MITCHELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of January
, 50 yards of cotton, value 4l., the goods of
George Washington England
, his master ; and
ELIZABETH MITCHELL
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen .

GEORGE WASHINGTON ENGLAND
. I am an upholsterer , and live in Welbeck-street
.
Leonard James Mitchell
was my errand-boy for about three weeks previous to the 15th of January - I discharged him on a Monday, I suppose about the 12th or the 14th, having missed various little trifling articles; after he was gone I missed fifty yards of cotton, which are in whole pieces, with the exception of one, which has had a yard or two taken off by the maker.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you any partner? A. No; this young woman had come to my house after the boy had left - I had found fault with some part of his conduct; I did tap him on the head with a child's boot - he did not threaten to take out a warrant for me.
COURT. Q. Do you know whether his sister visited him while he was there? A. She came once or twice to the shop, and she came after he was gone to know why he had left, and wished he might return.

JAMES STRINGER
. I live with Mr. Gofton, a pawnbroker. I have some cotton pawned by the female prisoner on the 7th of January.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you known her before? A. She had pawned some things, and released them again.

EBENEZER SOPER
. I am a dealer in these articles - I have a mark on this cotton; I sold it to the prosecutor.
MR. ENGLAND. I believe this to be mine, but I have no mark on it.
NOT GUILTY .

611.
JOHN KIFT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of February , 1 saddle, value 20s. , the goods of
Giles Bell Hutton
.

GILES BELL HUTTON
. I am a saddler , and live at Uxbridge
. I lost this saddle on the 3rd of February from a wooden horse at the door of my shop - the door stands in about six inches; it was market-day - I had the saddle in my possession at half-past ten o'clock, and missed it about twelve; I saw it again on the Saturday.

JAMES CHURCH
. I am a foot-patrol. I apprehended the prisoner on the Windsor road, about seven miles from Uxbridge, about half-past four o'clock, on the 3rd of February - he went into a harness-maker's shop, at Slough, and offered this saddle for sale; he said he would give me the saddle if I would let him go - as we were going back he threw down the saddle, and again said he would give it me to let him go - I took him to the Red Lion, and sent for the officer to take him.
JAMES BACON. I was sent for by Mr. Church, about half-past five o'clock, to take the prisoner - this is the saddle.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 55. -
Confined Six Months .

612.
HENRY SCARLETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of January , 2 books, value 16s. , the goods of
Samuel Daniel Ewins
.

JANE HEATH
. I live shop-woman to Mr. Samuel Daniel Ewins, a bookseller , of Duke-street, Smithfield
. On the 20th of January the prisoner, who was a stranger, came and said he wished to look at some books - I showed him some, and he told me to send them to a Mrs. Jones, No. 20, Barbican; he did not state his own name - I sent them there by the boy; the prisoner left, and as soon as he was gone I missed two books - I afterwards heard he was in custody: these books are Mr. Ewins'.

HENRY HALL
. I am shopman to Mr. Attenborough, a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned these two books on the 20th of January - he came again on the 22nd, andoffered another book; I detained him - these are the books, they are two Bibles and one Prayer-book.

WILLIAM ATTFIELD
. I was fetched to the pawnbroker's shop, and took the prisoner - I asked him how he came by the books he had pawned there; he said he had bought them in a large purchase of Mr. George Brown, of Birmingham, two years ago, but I found by the Prayer-book that it could not have been so, as it contains matter relative to the present Royal Family - I tied the prisoner's hands; he tried by all possible means to get away.

ELEANOR GROUTAGE
. This Prayer-book is mine.
Prisoner's Defence. These are pot what I got at Birmingham - I bought these in the street.
GUILTY . Aged 20.

613.
HENRY SCARLETT
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of January , 1 ring, value 2s.; 2 teaspoons, value 4s.; 1 shift, value 2s. 6d.; 1 sovereign, and 1 shilling , the property of
Sarah Brown
.

SARAH BROWN
. I am a widow , and live at No. 72, in Old-street-road
. The prisoner came to me as a lodger on the 27th of September; the last time I saw him was on the morning of the 18th of January - he told me he should return at night, but I did not see him again till he was at Worship-street - I had missed my property a long time before that.

WILLIAM ATTFIELD
. I took the prisoner on the 22nd of January - he said he lived at No. 3, Old-street-road, but I received information that he was living with an aunt of his in Hoxton Old-town; I went there, and asked what room he lodged in - I was shown up stairs; I looked about for books, but saw none - I saw a gold ring on the mantel-shelf; I did not take it then, but went to Mrs. Brown's - I found forty-eight duplicates in his room; one was for the tea-spoon, and one for a shift - I told Mrs. Brown I had seen a ring at his aunt's, and she said,"That is a ring which I lost;" I went back - the ring was not where I had seen it before, but I found it in the cellar; Mrs. Brown had described it as having been studded with red stones, except in three places, in which she had put black ones.

WILLIAM BURT
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a shift, pawned by the prisoner.

RICHARD LAW
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a teaspoon, pawned by the prisoner on the 27th of November.
MRS. BROWN. These are my property - I also lost a sovereign and a shilling, on the 1st or 2nd of December, out of my glass drawer.
Prisoner's Defence. The ring I found.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years for each offence .

614.
THOMAS PAPERA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of January , 13 casts of models in plaster, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Philip Papera
and another, to whom he was servant .

JAMES PHILIP PAPERA
. I am a modeller and figuremaker , in partnership with my mother, at No. 60, Marylebone-street, May-fair
- the prisoner is my cousin; he is not a partner - he was employed as a workman ; he had 36s. a week and his victuals. I lost several models and moulds too, but the stock is numerous, and I cannot tell when I missed them - I got a search-warrant, and went to the prisoner's; I knew where he lived, but I do not know the name of the place - I found these thirteen casts from models, which I knew to be our's; we did not find any models of legs and arms there.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe the prisoner is a very skilful workman? A. Yes - my mother had recently before this received an order from Lord Onslow to execute some figures, to the amount of 110l.; the prisoner had left my mother before that order was executed - the order was given at my house, and in my name; his Lordship did not direct that the prisoner should execute his order - it was not to be executed till the spring; I had a quarrel with my mother some time ago - I went away, but not far off; I did not go to live with the prisoner - I swear that; I have a house of my own in Elms-lane, Bayswater, where I reside - I am not married; I went before the Magistrate when the prisoner was committed - I did not then give charge of him for stealing some legs; I found the cast of a leg in Brujiarty's window, in Russel-street, and stated that to my mother - it was not from me that he received that model; he borrowed some models of me - I did not state to the Magistrate that I was the person who took the cast from the lady's leg, nor did I deny it; the question was not put to me - I did not state to the Magistrate that I and my uncle together took that cast; I did not deliver the leg to Mr. Brujiarty, or, if I did, it was unknown to me; I was not at Madame Vestris' when the model was taken - I have been to May-fair, but not to that lady's house; I sent the prisoner and his father - I was not turned out of the room on account of my youth; the gentleman who came to our shop said, "Don't let that man come, he is too young, send two elderly men;" I do not know that we had been directed not to part with that leg - I cannot swear that I did not lend the model of it to Brujiarty; he borrowed some moulds of legs of me - if this one was lent, it was with other moulds, and I did not know it; my mother took out the warrant for some other property - she reduced the prisoner's wages on account of had behaviour; Lord Onslow gave his order to the prisoner to bring to my house - I cannot tell how often in last year I had been at the prisoner's house; I might have gone several times to fetch him to work - I saw some casts there, but I never saw any of those now in Court; these casts are all mutilated - the prisoner has three or four children, who are in the habit of coming backwards and forwards for money; it is the custom in our business to throw aside mutilated casts in the shop - these are the casts; this one, in its present state, is worth nothing, but we can put a head to it, and then it would be worth 2s. 6d. - my man's time in making it would be worth 6d.; we did not know of these at the time the prisoner got Lord Onslow's order; we have so many about that I cannot tell when I had seen these - I never saw any of these models at the prisoner's house before we took them; I never slept in his house - I had a quarrel with my mother about several affairs, but not about money.
Q. Now your mother is here, upon your oath was it not about money? A. No, I never was charged with taking any money - I charged the prisoner with stealing casts, not models.
COURT. Q. Have you not been on the prisoner's premises, and seen them there before? A. No, never, my Lord - this charge did not originate in a suspicion that he would get Lord Onslow's order.

JOHN ANDREWS
. I am an officer. I went to the prisoner's, and found these casts among immense quantity of other things - they were on the mantel-piece in the cupboard, and different parts, not secreted in any manner.
Cross-examined. Q. Were they not broken? A. No, I believe I have broken this - they were whole when before the Magistrate.
NOT GUILTY .

615.
SARAH SHAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of January , 2 pairs of boots, value 3s. , the goods of
James Davey
.

ELIZA DAVEY
. I am the wife of
James Davey
- he keeps a shoemaker's-shop . On the 7th of January the prisoner lodged in the house, and slept in a private room which went into the shop; she left us without notice, and we missed two pairs of boots.

JOHN MARLOW
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Golden-lane. I have two pairs of children's boots, pawned by the prisoner, on the 7th of January.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 53. -
Confined Three Months .

616.
THOMAS WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of January , 28 quires of paper, value 1l. 5s., the goods of
Charles Roworth
and others .

CHARLES ROWORTH
. I am a letter-press printer , and am in partnership with my two sons - we live near Bellyard
. The prisoner is a total stranger to me. On the 20th of January I heard a noise - I came down, and found the prisoner in custody of one of our men, who had stopped him going out of our premises with some paper.

EDWARD LYON
. I am in the employ of Mr. Roworth. I was returning to his premises, and met the prisoner carrying this paper; I followed him about fifty yards, and asked what he had there - he said some paper, and that he was going home; he requested me to take it, but I refused- he came very quietly back with me, and acknowledged that he had taken it from the middle of the warehouse.
MR. ROWORTH. This is our paper - the prisoner pointed out the place he took it from, and pleaded distress.
Prisoner's Defence. I was cast away, and travelled up to london for employ, but could not get any.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Three Months .

617.
MARY WOODCOCK
and
MARY SMITH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of February , 26 yards of cotton, value 1l. , the goods of
James Brown
.

WILLIAM SHEATH
. I live with Mr.
James Brown
, a linen-draper , of Shadwell
. On the 10th of February the two prisoners came to his shop together, and looked at some printed cottons - I was standing by, and noticed that Smith held up several pieces rather higher than persons generally do, which concealed Woodcock very much; they still kept on together, and after some time I missed a piece of cotton from the counter, containing about sixteen yards - I looked for the Policeman, who came and found it up Woodcock's clothes, and another piece hanging to her tail; there was nothing found on Smith.

WILLIAM ROBERT GARDE
. I am a Police-constable. I went to the shop, and took the prisoners; I found this piece of cotton between Woodcock's legs, and as she was going out of the shop I saw about a yard of this other hanging behind her - I found no money on either of them.
WILLIAM SHEATH. These are my employer's property- they had both bartered and looked at the goods; they pretended to buy a dress, and said they would leave 1s. on it.

WOODCOCK -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

618.
ROBERT PASSINGHAM
and
JOHN RAYNER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 3 handkerchiefs, value 15s. , the goods of
Daniel Gibbon
.

THOMAS JOSEPH WEST
. I am a Police-constable. On Wednesday evening last I was in Coventry-street, St. James'
, and saw the two prisoners at Mr. Gibbon's shop window - he is a hosier and glover ; I saw Rayner go into the shop, while the other stood at the window - he returned with something in his hand, which he gave to Passingham, who put it under his coat on the left side; Hobbs took Rayner, and I took Passingham - I found these three handkerchiefs under his coat.

Cross-examined by MR. CARRINGTON. Q. About what time was this? A. Between seven and eight o'clock - it was dark, except from the gas-lights; there were no persons looking into the window at that time but the prisoners.

THOMAS HOBBS
. I am a Police-constable. I was with West, and saw the two prisoners looking in at the window- I saw Rayner go into the shop, take hold of the handkerchiefs, and give them several tugs, till he got them down- he brought them out, and gave them to Passingham, who took them backwards.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Are you quite certain as to the person of Passingham? A. Yes, I am; it was all done in less than five minutes - I was close to them- there was a waggon stopping close to the door, and I whipped round it and caught them.

THOMAS CAFFIN
. I am a shopman to Mr.
Daniel Gibbon
. These three handkerchiefs are his property, and were hanging at his door - I saw them safe in the afternoon, and missed them in the evening.
Cross-examined by MR. CARRINGTON. Q. Have you any mark on them? A. No; I think we had the pieces of these handkerchiefs for three months - we sold five of them.
The prisoners received a good character.
PASSINGHAM - GUILTY. Aged 15.
RAYNER - GUILTY. Aged 13.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury . -
Confined 3 Months .

619.
WILLIAM MACK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of January , 10 gallons of wine, value 10l., and 60 bottles, value 10s., the goods of
John Whinery Spencer
, his master .

JOHN WHINERY SPENCER
. I live in Newton-street, Holborn
. The prisoner was in my employ, as household-servant , for eighteen months; I had for a long time missed wine from my private wine-cellar, and on the 10th of January, when I went to get some brandy, I missed a quantity of that; I missed wine every time I went - I askedmy son if he had taken any; he said No - he then came down into the cellar, and we laid a plan to detect the thief, by putting this detonating snap; some of the wine was twenty-four years old, and some ten years old - when I returned to town the next morning the prisoner, who had been detected, said he had taken the wine, and drank it, broken the bottles, and thrown them with the other broken bottles; I had lost a key of the cellar for six months.

WILLIAM SPENCER
. I knew of the snap having been put on the door, and about half-past eight o'clock in the evening on the 11th of January, I heard the prisoner go across the warehouse, and down to the wine-cellar - I heard the snap go off, and I went down and took him; he denied then that he had taken any wine, but the next morning he said he had taken it, and drank it - Mr. Spencer has lost not less than six dozen of wine, besides brandy.

Prisoner's Defence. His son is cohabiting with a lady in Burton-crescent, and he had been in the habit of sending wine there - I have been afraid to say any thing, because he acted as a sort of deputy master over me; they let me go home that night, and then took me the next morning - they got two men there to frighten me, and asked if I knew of any body else being guilty.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

620.
JOHN MILAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of December , 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
Patrick Stack
.

PATRICK STACK. I lodged in Bainbridge-street, St. Giles'
, in the same room with the prisoner. I have known him since May last - he wanted to buy a pair of shoes of me, but I said I wanted them myself; I went out about two o'clock, on the 29th of December, and when I returned, he had gone out with my shoes - I met him on the the 25th of January, with them on his feet, and gave him in charge; I had never lent them to him - he works for the parish, at watering the streets in summer time, and at other times he sings ballads .

Prisoner's Defence. I asked him to let me have them, and he refused - I was much in want of them, and when he was going out, I asked him to lend them to me; I thought he said Yes - there were five or six persons in the room when I put them on, and I left my own under the table.
NOT GUILTY .

621.
FRANCES KEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of January . 1 counterpane, value 2s. 6d., and 1 bed-tick, value 6s. , the goods of
Thomas Parker
.

THOMAS PARKER. I live in George-street, St. Giles'
. The prisoner lived in a furnished room, in a house of mine in the next street - she had been there about three months. On the 31st of January I went into her room, because she owed me some rent - I went home, and told my wife to go and look over the things, which she did, and discovered that the articles stated were missing; the prisoner had taken the flock out of the tick, and news it up in a sheet - she afterwards gave me these duplicates.

GEORGE MACKEY
. I live with Mr. Wells, a pawnbroker. I have a counterpane, for which I gave this duplicate.

THOMAS JEROME
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a bedtick, which this is the duplicate of.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she had pawned the goods to pay her rent with, and intended to redeem them if she had time, and that the prosecutor kept a house of ill fame, known by the name of "Mothers Common's."

THOMAS PARKER
. I keep a lodging-house, but I keep it honestly - I found 300l. in it once, and I advertized it.
Q. Do you keep such a house? A. I do, but that is no reason why I should be robbed.
NOT GUILTY .

622.
MARY BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February , 1 cup, value 2s. 6d., and 1 saucer, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
George Evans
.

SARAH MOULDER
. I live with Mr.
George Evans
, at Ealing
. On the 13th of February the prisoner came begging to his gate, and went into the parlour - the house stands back, and has a garden before it; when I saw her she was at the parlour door, and I know she had been in the parlour, as the door had been shut, and it was then open - I went and took her by the gate; she had this cup and saucer, which had been taken from the parlour, one on one side, and the other on the other, in the baby's mantle.

JOHN FINCHER
. I stopped the prisoner at the gate, with this cup and saucer.
Prisoner's Defence. It was distress drove me to it - it was only the day before that, I took my shift off, and sold it for 8d.; my parish is Portsmouth.

SARAH MOULDER
. She had asked charity of me about a week before, but she did not on that day - I believe she lodged at Brentford.

GUILTY . Aged 43. -
Confined Six Months .

623.
LEONARD GIBSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 7 lbs. of beef, value 3s. , the goods of
John Owen
.

JOHN OWEN. I have a butcher's-shop in Fitzroy-market
. About half-past ten o'clock on Saturday night, the 12th of February, I was returning from my other shop, and met the prisoner and another boy - they came in front of my shop, where my wife was weighing some mutton; my servant had just gone away - they both took hold of the piece of beef; they came right into my arms with it -I caught hold of the prisoner, and the beef; the other got away - I had seen them take the beef off my board; it weighed 7 1/2 lbs.
Prisoner. This is the first crime I ever committed - I was returning home last Christmas, and saw four men round the prosecutor's shop; I went and told him of it.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

624.
ALICE COOPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of January , 1 pair of stockings, value 5s.; 1 cap, value 3s.; 1 bracelet, value 2s.; 1 necklace, value 5s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 3s., and 2 cups. of tea, value 6d. , the goods of
Ellen Shaw
.

ELLEN SHAW
. I live in Union-street, Middlesex-hospital
. I had worked at a place at which the prisoner lived servant , and when she was out of place she offered to cometo assist me in washing - this was on the Wednesday; when she was gone I missed the articles stated in the indictment - they have all been found at her lodging, except she stockings, which she had on - she came to me again on the Saturday afterwards - I sent for an officer; she was charged with the robbery, and dented it.

WILLIAM ESKETT
. I am an officer. I was sent for to the prosccutrix's room - I took the prisoner to the watch-house; she at first said she lived at 1slington, but afterwards she said it was of no use telling an untruth - she then gave me her address in Charlton-street, Marylebone; I found these things there; the stockings she had on.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Three Months .

Fifth Middlesex Jury. before Mr. Connons Sergeant. 625.
SUSAN AKENHEAD
was indicted
for stealnig, on the 20th of January , 3 pairs of shoes, value 16s. , the goods of
John Howard
.
The articles being half-boots. the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

626.
SUSAN AKENHEAD
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of December , 1 pair of shoes, value 4s. , the goods of
John Howard
.
These alson being half-boots, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

627.
JAMES BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of January , 1 pair of scales, value 10s. , the goods of
Saville Thomas Forst
.

SAVILLE THOMAS FORST. On the 24th of January I received information from
John Carney
, and missed a pair of scales from my shop - I found them in the officer's posseassion.

JOHN CARNEY. I live in Parker-street, Long-acre
, nearly opposite the prosecutor's. On the 24th of January I was standing nearly opposite his shop, and saw the prisoner make two attempts to take something from the shop; the third time he went back and took the scales; I took him about ten yards off with them - I gave them to the officer.

JOHN BLOOM
. I am Police-officer. I received these scales.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY. Aged 11. -
Judgment Respited
.

628.
JOHN COURT
was indicted for
stealing. on the 28th of December , 1 coat, value 5s., the goods of
Samuel Challis
; 1 coat, value 2s., and 1 shirt, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Kitchener
.

SAMUEL CHALLIS. I lodged in Bainbridge-street, St. Giles
, for about three months - the prisoner lodged there. On the 27th of December I had a coat given me; 1 hung it on a line - on getting up the next morning I missed it, about the dawn of that day - the prisoner had gone out at five o'clock that morning; he had lodged in the same room - I did not see him again till the 6th of January, when I met him in Buckeridge-street; I seized him - he said he was very sorry for what had occurred, and he would make it up by giving me something to eat; he was taken to the watch-house, and said he had borrowed the coat of Kitchener, who lodged in the house.

THOMAS KITCHENER
. I lodge in the same room with the prosecutor. I missed a coat and shirt on the 28th of December - I have seen them in the officer's possession; the shirt was by the fire, and the prisoner asked me to lend him the coat to throw over his bed.
Prisoner. The coat and shirt were lent to me. Witness. I only lent him the coat to throw over his bed - I did not lend the shirt at all.

JOHN REEVE
. I am a Police-constable. The prisoner was given to my charge - I took a coat and a shirt off his person.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of Challis' coat- this coat and shirt Kitchener lent me.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Six Months .

629.
CHARLES JARVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of February , 1 picture, value 10s., and 4 picture-frames, value 2l. , the goods of
Josiah Morgan
.

JOSEPH CLEMENTS
. I am a Police-constable. On Wednesday, the 2nd of February, I was in Tottenham-place, about ten minutes past eleven o'clock at night; I saw a coach coming to the end of Tottenham-place, and saw the prisoner coming out of Southampton-court, and another man about ten yards in front of him - they were going towards the coach; the prisoner had the articles here produced - I asked what he had there; he made me no answer - I caught him, and pulled him round - the other man, and the coach then disappeared; I again asked the prisoner what he had there - he said pictures, and that the man in front of him had given him 6d. and a glass of gin to carry them to the coach; I took him to the station-house.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was the other man nearer to the coach? A. He was about ten yards in front of the prisoner; neither of them were within sixty yards of the coach - the prisoner was going towards the coach; here is one picture of His Majesty, the rest are frames and this crown and cushion - I found nothing on him suspicious.

JOSIAH MORGAN. I live at No. 51, London-street, Fitzroy-square
, and am a picture-frame maker . These frames, crown and cushion, are mine, and this portrait - I missed them on Wednesday evening, the 2nd of February, between six and eight o'clock - I found the door of my shop open at eight, and the glass-case door open; I had seen them safe at dusk, about six o'clock.
Cross-examined. Q. Then these things must have been gone before eight o'clock? A. Yes.
Prisoner's Defence. I told him to catch hold of the man before me, as he had given me the goods to carry.
NOT GUILTY .

630.
WILLIAM CARTER
was indicted for
stealing. on the 27th of January , 1 bevil, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John Brickell
.

JOHN BRICKELL. I live at No. 127, Tottenham-court-road
, and am a pawnbroker - I have a board in front of my window, on which I place articles for sale. On the 27th of January I looked through my window, saw the prisoner take the bevil, and put it into his fob - I let him go two doors, then went, and took him back; he denied having it, and at the same time it dropped from his trousers.

SAMPSON CHAMPION
. I am a Police-constable. Theprisoner was given into my custody - I found nothing on him, but a brass cock.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 30.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Months .

631.
WILLIAM DOBSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of February , I handkerchief, value 3s. , the goods of
John Walter Walker
.

JOHN WALTER WALKER. I live at Park-house, Turnham-green, Middlesex. On the evening of the 5th of February I was walking with my wife, in Drury-lane
; a constable gave me information - I put my hand to my pocket, and missed my handkerchief - I have since seen it produced by Dowding, and to the best of my belief it was mine, but I cannot swear to it, because it was lent me by a friend; I had one in my pocket, and when the officer called my attention to it it was gone.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe you had considerable difficulty in saying that it was the one you had lost? A. Yes, as it had been so short a time in my possession, I could not conscientiously swear to it; I stated so to the Magistrate in the first place - the officer had been examined then; he then added that he saw the man take it from my pocket, having before said he found it - I said I could not swear to it, and the Magistrate was about to discharge the prisoner; the officer then said there was no occasion to discharge him, for he saw him take it from my pocket - the officer had not been examined first; I know Dowding was sworn - I do not know whether Groom was.

COURT. Q. You were not aware your handkerchief was lost till your attention was called to it; you then missed it, and before the Magistrate you expressed considerable doubt about it? A. No; I said I could tell it by a stain which I recognized, and I pointed out that stain, but I said I would not swear to it.

GEORGE DOWDING
. I live at No. 15, Rose-street, Long-acre, and am a constable. A little after seven o'clock in the evening, on the 5th of February, I was in Drury-lane, near Long-acre; I saw the prosecutor walking with a lady, and I saw the prisoner, whom I had not known before, in company with another person - i saw the prisoner touch the gentleman's pocket several times, and at last he put his hand into his right-hand coat pocket, and took out a silk hankderchief; he ran across towards Groom, and I called to him to stop him - the prisoner threw the handkerchief into the road; I took it up, and told the prosecutor he had lost his handkerchief - he identified it as his property.

Cross-examined. Q. He knew it at once? A. Yes, he had no doubt of its being his property; he identified it both to me, and at the office - he pointed out a stain, and swore he had no doubt of it, but the fact is, the gentleman did not wish to prosecute, as there was so much trouble attending it.

Q. Now, which is the truth - did he swear to it or did he not? A. He did swear to it to the best of my knowledge, and I believe that was taken down; I think I was examined after the prosecutor - I saw the prisoner make two or three attempts at the prosecutor's pocket; I was across the road - I saw him for five minutes; I am an officer - I am serving in my own right this year; I served for five years as a substitute - I am a tailor; it all helps to bring in a crust to support my family - I am both a master and a journeyman tailor; I work as journeyman for Mr. Stringer, in Long-acre; I generally get about 10l. for acting as a subsitute - I had a good many cases here last year, but I only had my expences in one case at one Session.

JOHN GROOM
. I am a constable. On the evening of the 5th of February I was in Drury-lane; I saw the prisoner, and another person with him, following a lady and this gentleman - Dowding called out "Groom;" and I saw the prisoner running from the lady and gentleman with a handkerchief in his hand - he dropped the handkerchief, and I told Dowding to take it up, and to run after the lady and gentleman; I took the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you show the gentleman the handkerchief, and did he say it was his? A. Yes, he had no doubt of it; and at the office he said it was one he had borrowed of a friend - I am in no business; I did not see any more persons about the place but the prisoner and his companion; I had known the prisoner before - his clothes had no pockets - I am sure the prosecutor said he had no doubt it wasthe same handkerchief.
Prisoner. I have the same clothes on now; I have pockets in them.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined One Year .

632.
THOMAS FRANCIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of January , I handkerchief, value 6d., and 1 half-sovereign , the property of
David Walker
.

SARAH WALKER
. I am the wife of
David Walker
; we live in Collingwood-street, Ratcliff
; the prisoner lodged there for seven months. On the 17th of January I sent him with a newspaper to a neighbouring public-house, and he did not return; soon after he was gone I missed a half-sovereign from a cupboard in a room, which I had seen safe half an hour or twenty minutes before -I in general keep the room locked, but having no one in the house but the prisoner I had not locked it that day -I do not recollect that he had been in that room; I had not sent him there - I never saw him again till the officer brought him, which was more than a week afterwards; I asked how he could have a heart to rob a woman who had been so kind to him; he said he put the half-sovereign into his pocket and lost it, and he had been to Gravesend to try to get a ship, but could not - I missed a handkerchief, and found a duplicate of it.

GEORGE BLAKE
. I am a Police-constable. On the 25th of January, in consequence of information, I took the prisoner at Cock-hill; I asked if he knew any thing of Mrs. Walker - he said Yes; I asked if he knew any thing of the half-sovereign - he said Yes, that he had not changed lit but lost it, and that he had just returned from Gravesend.

WILLIAM LANCE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a cotton handkerchief pawned by the prisoner, on the 17th of January, for 3d.; it is worth about 6d.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I took the half-sovereign, put it into my pocket and lost it; I went to Gravesend - I had only 1½d. on the handkerchief.
GUILTY. Aged 25.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutrix and Jury.

Judgment Respited
.

633.
CHARLES HAYNES
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 16th of January , 2 horses, price 20l., and 1 mare, price 10l., the property of
William Elson
, well knowing them to have been stolen ; against the Statute, & c.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM ELSON. I live at Bramshot, near Liphook, in Hampshire. On the 14th of January I had three pony horses and a mare - one of the horses was brown, another a dark brown, and the third a black stallion; the mare was brown - on that day they had been employed in carrying stones on the road, and I put them up about four o'clock at night; I saw them safe in the stable between seven and eight - I got up in the morning between five and six, found the stable door broken, thrown open, and the mare, the black horse, and one of the brown ones were gone; as soon as it got day-light I looked about, and tracked two men on a dung-hill, and off again; I also tracked the feet of three borses behind a cart, up the hill, where they had turned off towards the common, and a cart appeared to have been tied to a hedge - the horses appeared to have been tied behind the cart, and to have hung back when they first started - I followed the track on for ten miles in the London road, towards Godalming; I afterwards came to London, where I saw Pople and Curtis - I missed the horses on a Saturday morning, and came to London on the Thursday following; I went to Union-ball, and saw the officers - they produced the two horses and the mare which I had lost, all three together; I am quite sure they are my horses, and were what I had seen safe in my stable.

SARAH KITCHING
. I am the wife of
Thomas Kitching
- he is a publican, and keeps the Bee Hive public-house, at Hayes, or Yeading - I know the prisoner; he had slept in our house. On the morning of Saturday, the 15th of January, I went to the door about eleven, or between eleven and twelve o'clock, and saw the prisoner standing at our stable door - he had a black pony, with a long tail, with him; at the same time I saw a person go by in a cart - it was in consequence of what I saw that person do that I looked to the stable door, and saw the prisoner - when the prisoner had put the pony into the stable, he came into my house, with the saddle on his arm - he had something to drink; I believe a small glass of brandy; he then went away, but came again in the course of the day, slept there that night, and came down stairs the next morning while we were at breakfast; I had noticed the man with the cart had another horse tied at the side - my son came home late on that Saturday night; I saw the same pony which I had seen at the stable door, in the possession of the officer in London - I have not the least doubt of its being the same; I know a cottage near the Bee Hive, in which Moffatt, who I had seen in the cart, and a man named Holding, live - they were acquainted with the prisoner; I had seen them altogether often - the prisoner, Moffat, Holding, and two other friends had supped together at our house on that Saturday night.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you say at the last trial that you had seen these men often together? A. I will not swear that I did - it was in the middle of the day that I saw him with the pony by our stable door; our house stands a little way back from the public road, but it joins it - he could not have got to the stable without going along the public road; I think I had known him three months before: I do not know whether he is in the habit of buying and selling horses - I think I had seen him with a horse once before, but he generally came to Moffat's, and walked from there to our house - we do not keep an ostler; the prisoner gave me no charge to keep it secret - the pony was put into the stable, to which travellers or strangers might have access.

THOMAS KITCHING
. JUN. I am the son of Mrs. Kitching. I came home on Saturday night, the 15th of January, between six and seven o'clock - I remember seeing the prisoner next morning up against our door; he had a black pony, with a long tail; he called out to me, "Who is the boy for a ride;" I said, "Yes, if you like" - he helped me on the pony, and told me to take him down to my father's orchard, which I did, and the prisoner followed me; I took the halter off the pony, turned him loose, and the prisoner told me to drive him up amongst my father's horses, which I did - I saw that pony afterwards in the stable by Union-hall; I am sure it was the same pony - I think it was the week afterwards.

Cross-examined. Q. Were there any white spots about this black pony? A. I did not take notice of that in particular - I did not observe whether there was a large white spot on one of his sides, nor whether the left ear was cropped, or whether he had two white fore-legs; but I know the horse I saw afterwards was the one I rode I did not notice whether he had a white spot on his forehead, but I am sure the horse I saw was the same I rode- it was about fifteen miles from our house to where I saw him again in town; I should have known him any where, but not by any particular mark; he was not a very remarkable horse - I did not say at Union-hall I would not swear to the horse, not to my recollection; I cannot swear I did not - I had seen the prisoner about twice before that day; I knew his name was Charles; he had been at my father's on the Saturday night and the Sunday night.

THOMAS KITCHING
, SEN. I keep the Bee Hive, at Hayes. On Saturday morning, the 15th of January, I went to my stable, between seven and eight o'clock; there were no horses in the stable then - they were all at work; I went out on a journey, and returned about four in the afternoon - I went to my stable, and saw a black stallion pony, with a long tail; I afterwards saw the same pony in possession of Pople and Curtis, the officers - I know it was the same.

Cross-examined. Q. You took notice of it? A. Yes, I had seen it in my journey - I met the prisoner and Moffatt with a cart; one horse was in the shafts of the cart, one tied to the shafts, and this black pony following behind, either tied or very close to the cart - there was no man in the cart; Moffatt was behind the cart, and the prisoner about twenty yards behind him - I do not know where Liphook is, but I met them on the road between the Uxbridge and the Bath roads, about ten o'clock on the Saturday morning; I did not see them talk together, but they were going in a direction towards Moffatt's house - I am sure there were only two men; I had known the prisoner about two months - he had slept at my house abouta week before; I had never seen him buy or sell horses - he had put one up; I did not take particular notice of the left ear of the pony - the whole ear was not off, there might be a bit of it off; it was a white-faced pony - the greater part of his face was white; I did not see that he had white legs - I did not notice the two fore-legs, but it was a stallion - it had a long tail, a white face, and the pony I saw at Union-hall was the same pony; the legs might have been all white for what I know - the tall was not white; the prisoner slept at my house on the Saturday night, and had a cup of tea there on Sunday morning - I saw no secrecy about him.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. This was about ten o'clock? A. Yes - I saw the pony in possession of the officer the next day, and knew it to be the same.

RICHARD POPLE. I am an officer of Union-hall.
