I heard of the loss of Elson's horses, and in consequence of information, I went down to Hayes, with Curtis, on the 16th of January - we went to a cottage, about one hundred yards from the Bee Hive; I understand that is about forty miles from Lipbook, but I do not know it - when we got to the cottage, Curtis went in first; the door opens into the kitchen, and I saw a bay mare standing before the fireplace - I heard a noise backwards, and ran to the back door; I saw a woman holding her hand out - I saw the prisoner running across the orchard, and Curtis after him; Curtis had a pair of pistols. and I heard him threaten to shoot the prisoner if he did not stop - the prisoner had got over a gate and a ditch into the road; I returned to the kitchen - the mare was still there; I looked and saw some hair about, and I saw the mare had been cropped in the fetlocks - I then went to the stable belonging to the house, and found the two stallions; the prisoner, the two stallions, and the mare, were all brought to London - they all had long tails; Mr. Elson saw them, and claimed them.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see nobody else at the cottage, but the woman and the prisoner? A. I saw no other person in the cottage - I saw a man outside the door; I did not speak to him - I will swear I did not say to him."Did not I see you somewhere before?" I do not recollect that Curtis spoke to him - he might, and I not hear it; I was not asked on the last trial any thing about seeing the mare outside - he was about twenty yards from the road; he was perhaps ten or twenty yards from the cottage - I think he was coming from it; I did not see him come out of it - I really do not recollect seeing Curtis at the moment I saw that man; he might be engaged in the stable - he did not speak to the man in my presence; I saw a chaise on the premises - I did not ask that man whose it was, but I think I asked the prisoner.

ROBERT CURTIS
. I am an officer of Union-hall. I went with Pople to Hayes on the 16th of January - we went to a cottage in the neighbourhood of the Bee Hive; I went in first - I saw a mare in the room; I saw a woman in a passage leading to another room, wave her hand, as if to some person in the back part of the house - I ran to the back door, and saw the prisoner crossing an orchard; he went through a hedge, and then over a gate, into the road- I called to him. presented a pistol, and said I would shoot him if he did not stop; I took him back to the kitchen, and saw a trifle of hair had been clipped off from the fetlock joint of the mare - we then went to the stable, where I saw two ponies; one was brown, and the other black, with a streak of white down the face - we took them and the mare to London, showed them to Elson on the Thursday following, and he identified them as his property; Mrs. Kitching saw the black pony, and said she believed it was the one she had seen at the stable. and Mr. Kitching said it was the same; when we got to the Adam and Eve, about a quarter of a mile from the Bee Hive, where my horse and chaise was, the prisoner said he did not live at the cottage; I asked where he did live - he said he lodged at the Bee Hive; I asked him when - he said,"The whole of last week"

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see any man at the cottage, or near the cottage, where you saw the woman? A. yes, there were persons in the road - I saw a man, and spoke to him, but did not ask him any question; I saw a chaise in the yard belonging to the stable.
Q. Did you ever say you believed this man stole the pony? A. No, I believe he was in league with others -I never did say I believed he stole the pony individually.

Q. Did you ever swear it? now be careful, for your own sake, A. No, I never was asked the question; I never said that at the time the pony was stolen he was passing through the turnpike-gate, in a direction from the place where it was stolen from; I said three men were seen, I did not say he was one of them - it was before the prisoner was tried for stealing them, that I said I could prove three men passed through the turnpike-gate.

Q. Did you ever say this, or any thing like it, that you could bring evidence to prove that the prisoner was seen coming from the road leading from Liphook towards the Bee Hive? A. I have said that witnesses could prove that three men were seen - I do not know the prisoner was one; I never said I could have witnesses to prove that the prisoner was seen on the road - I said three men were seen at a village below.

Q. Was it not upon your swearing at Union-ball that you believed the prisoner stole the horses, that he was remanded? A. No, he was remanded on the charge of having committed divers felonies and horse-stealing, in the County of Hants.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you afterwards show the prosecutor the horses? A. Yes, and he identified them.

COURT to
THOMAS KITCHING
, SEN. Q. You have stated that on the morning of the 15th of January, you met Moffatt with a cart, a horse tied to the shaft, and another tied behind? A. I will not say he was tied - he was very close to the cart; that was between two and three miles from my house, and it was about ten o'clock as near as I can guess.

COURT to
ROBERT CURTIS
. Q. Did you at any time state that you believed this man stole the horse? A. I believed that till I was convinced, by what passed in the other Court, that it was not so.

COURT to MRS. KITCHING. Q. Could not the prisoner as easily have taken the pony to the house where the mare was found, as he could have brought him to your house? A. Yes, it is about the same little distance from the road.
Prisoner's Defence. My Lord and Gentlemen of the Jury - I leave it to them to answer whether I should have taken the pony to the Bee Hive, if I had known it was stolen - I am quite innocent.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Baron Bailey.

634.
JOHN MASTERS
was charged, on the
Coroner's inquisition only, for killing and slaying
Julia Masters
.

MR.
GEORGE DUPLEX
, a surgeon, and MR. DALEY, his assistant, deposed, that in their opinion the deceased had died from"pure apoplexy," and that there were no markwhatever of recent external violence, the witnesses were, therefore, not examined.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Baron Bailey,

635.
JOHN BARRETT
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
John Shannon
, and with a certain sharp instrument, unlawfully, wilfully, and unaliciously cutting him, with intent to kill and murder him .
SECOND COUNT, stating his intent to be to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JOHN SHANNON. I came from Limerick, in lreland, and work for the Corporation of the Trinity-house. - I have known the prisoner almost ever since he was born. Last Saturday night three weeks I went into the Rose and Crown, at Wapping
, between six and seven o'clock; the prisoner was there before I went in, and left before me - I had been in no quarrel there; I went home between nine and ten; I sent my wife out for something for supper - the window happened to be open, and within two doors of my house I heard my child, who is about ten years old, make an alarm that his mother was killed outside; I live on the first floor - I ran down into the street; the child had made a report that there were three people, but I saw only the prisoner and my wife - I said to the prisoner, "Is that you, you villain,
Jack Barrett
, that is making a row, and using my wife so?" he made no answer; he stooped down, as I thought, for a stone, and cut me either with a knife or razor between the calf of my leg and my ancle, at the back of my leg; I might have touched him, but never struck him, nor did I go towards him in a menacing manner, nor had I touched him roughly - I had not touched him before I was cut; we never had any words since we were born - I know of no ill-will on his part towards me; when I found I was cut I went home, and was carried from there to the doctor's - I was afterwards carried to the London-hospital, and have been brought from there this morning; I am still lame - I cannot stand on my leg.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you mean to say you went home immediately you were cut? A. I do - I never struck the prisoner at all; he did not call Murder! I saw nobody come to his assistance - I saw him laying down on the ground, about ten minutes after he struck me; I had come out, and gone along the wall to give him in charge - he might have called for assistance before I came up; I was not on the top of him - I was tried at Hick's-hall about nine years ago for a common assault; I saw Maloney in the street - he and Flannigan took me to the doctor's; they did not rescue the prisoner from me - I was not on him, nor beating him; Flannigan was three or four perches off when this occurred.

CATHERINE SHANNON. I am the prosecutor's wife. He came home on this Saturday night - he was not in liquor; he sent me out for some supper, and when I got down I and a young Irish woman, named Mrs. Angledon, an acquaintance of the prisoner's, had some words within three or four doors of my house; she made an offer to hit me, and when she made that offer she fell - I did not strike at her; the prisoner then came up to me, hit me in the breast, and while I was down that woman's husband came and gave me a kick - I hallooed out Murder! I had not seen that woman for some weeks before; when they heat me and I fell, my cloak went over my face, and I did not see what happened to my husband, nor hear him say any thing - when I got up I went up stairs to my children, who were crying; whether my husband was hurt then I cannot tell - I heard no noise in the street; my boy came up in about five minutes, and said his father had been hurt - when I came down stairs the second time my husband was taken to Dr. Benson's; I went there, and he was taken to the London-hospital the same night by Maloney and John Flannigan, in a truck.

Cross-examined. Q. How long were you up stairs before you came down? A. About ten minutes - I did not see the prisoner then, I saw my husband; I had had part of two pints of beer between me, my husband, and another man and his wife, at the Dolphin, about nine o'clock - I was not at the Rose and Crown; my children were in bed, except the infant which I had in my arms - my husband had no row that night, to my knowledge; he came straight from the pay-table - I swear I heard of no row between him and a man named Russel, outside the Rose and Crown; I went to the Dolphin with him about eight o'clock - we staid there an hour or an hour and a half; no spirits were drank - I never struck Mrs. Angledon, nor touched her; I never saw my husband outside the Rose and Crown that night - I know he had been there, for he is paid there.

JOHN FLANNIGAN
. I live at Wapping. I saw Shannon last Saturday three weeks, about ten o'clock, close to his own house; he was not wrangling nor struggling with any body that I saw - I saw him wounded by Barrett; I had been with him three or four minutes - the prisoner was not there then; he came up three or four minutes after I first met Shannon - he was not there when I first saw him; as soon as he came up Shannon made towards him - I cannot tell whether it was to lay hold of him and give him in charge, or to strike him; it appeared to me to be for one of those purposes - I think he laid his hands somewhere or other on him; he appeared to lay his hands pretty roughly on him, and said, "Is this you you villain,
Jack Barrett
, that has struck my wife?" and with that the prisoner stooped down and cut Shannon Shannon had been in the street three or four minutes before the prisoner came up; I did not see Mrs. Shannon - Shannon was only going on home; we were walking down the street - we had walked four or five perches; he had told me if he met the prisoner he would give him in charge - I was examined at the office; what I said was read over to me before I signed it.

Q. Did you not say there "I found the prisoner and a man named Shannon struggling together, and I went to Shannon's assistance?" A. Yes, they were struggling; when they met he went and took him, and they had a struggle - I had been walking with Shannon for three orfour minutes before; they did not meet together for two or three minutes; I saw a clasp-knife in the prisoner's hands when he came up - it was open; he was coming up against Shannon - whether they had been together before I cannot tell.

Cross-examined. Q. Was Shannon struggling with any body when you first saw him? A. Not when I met him, but when Barrett met him they were struggling together for about a minute, holding one another; Shannon had hold of the prisoner somewhere about his breast, and the prisoner held him somewhere about his waistband, but where I cannot say - Shannon thought to lay hold of him to keep him for the Police - the prisoner struggled away and cut him; they struggled about a minute before he cut him - I took the prosecutor home; Maloney took him to the doctor's, and I went back to give charge of Barrett - he ran away after cutting the prosecutor; I ran after him, tried to take him, and he cut me - I upset him; I told the Magistrate Maloney helped to take him home and to the doctor's; I do not know whether that was taken down - I had had no words with the prisoner; I had not been to his father's that night to challenge him to fight a boy named Russell - I know Russell; he had not quarrelled with the prisoner at the Rose and Crown that night in my presence; I had been at his father's that night, but did not say the prisoner should fight Russell for a sovereign, and if Russell did not beat him I would beat him well - I went there with the Police to give him in charge; I did not go before - I never said any thing of the kind; I had been drinking at the Rose and Crown that night - it is our house of call; I was there three of four hours - Barrett was there part of the time; I do not know whether Russell was there, but it is our house of call - he left about half-past nine; I cannot tell whether Shannon went with me - I was sober; he was not in my company, but might be in the room - we work in a different craft; he might leave sooner or later - I was not there when the Police were called in; I never heard of it; I was not at the Dolphin.
COURT. Q. Do you mean to say you saw the knife in his hand when first you saw him coming towards Shannon? A. Yes, and it was open; he had a small bit of bread in his hand, as I understand.

Q. Was not what you said to the Magistrate "I wanted to part them both asunder, Shannon called out that his leg was cut, I turned over to the prisoner to lay hold of him, and with that I saw a knife in his hand?" A. Yes; directly he came up I saw it in his hand - I only saw one knife in his hand that night; he came back with the very knife I saw in his hand.

Q. Did you not say with another knife? A. Yes, the Police have got that; I saw but one knife - I know where the prisoner's father lives, but do not know the name of the court; he was coming from his own home when he met Shannon; I did not see Mrs. Shannon in the street - it was about half-past ten o'clock, as far as I understand.

SARAH LOW
. I live in Green Arbour-alley, nearly opposite the Police-station. I believe I saw the prisoner on Sunday morning - it was between twelve and one o'clock, nearer one; I heard the clock strike one soon after I shut my window down.

CATHERINE SHANNON
. It was nearly twelve o'clock when my husband was cut - I think it was before twelve, because the shops were open; he had been up stairs for above an hour or more before this happened - the shops are shut at near twelve o'clock; my husband went home a little after ten - he sent me out in about an hour and a half.
JOHN SHANNON. This happened between eleven and twelve o'clock, as near as I can say, but I cannot say exactly, for we have no clock - I cannot say whether it was before twelve.
JOHN FLANNIGAN. The prisoner was apprehended about twelve or one o'clock - I went to his father's house with the Police; it was about an hour after this happened, as near as I can tell.
SARAH LOW re-examined. I saw the prisoner sharpen a knife between twelve and one o'clock - I was three quarters of an hour at my window, and it struck one soon after I shut it down.

Q. Your deposition states that soon after you opened your window the clock struck one? A. That is a mistake - I gave my evidence that it was between twelve and one o'clock; I saw him sharpen a knife on the step of a door; my deposition was not read over to me - I said that between twelve and one o'clock I heard a disturbance, and opened my window; I cannot tell who made the disturbance - the prisoner was one of them; I saw him with his father and mother - two Policemen were trying to take him home; he went home with them to his father's, and came out again five minutes after the Policemen left - he came up the alley, and I saw him sharpen the knife on a step three doors off; it was a moon-light - I was up two pairs of stairs, and cannot say whether he was in liquor - he went up the alley, on the green bank, and I heard a cry of Murder! three times; I believe the green bank is where Shannon was struck.

Cross-examined. Q. What office did you give your deposition at? A. The Thames Police; the Magistrate was present, but I signed it in a little room - the clerk was there; he did not read it over to me - I was sworn.

COURT. Q. Had you heard the clock strike twelve? A. Yes - I was then folding up some work, and was about five minutes before I went to my bed-room, and in ten or fifteen minutes after I went up, I heard the noise, and opened the window; I was making my bed.

JOHN EASTERBROOK
. I am a Police-serjeant. Our watch-house is on the green bank - Shannon was brought there between twelve and one o'clock, (nearer one,) by Flannigan, his wife, and two or three more; he was wounded then - I had seen the prisoner about twelve, and endeavoured with his father and mother to prevail on him to go home; Robson, another Policeman, was with me - I took him part of the way down the court, and sent the other Policeman home with him; whether he went out afterwards I do not know - he was not drunk, but rather the worse for liquor; Robson had taken a clasp-knife from him; when Shannon was brought in he was cut just below the calf of the left leg; Shannon's house looks on to the green bank - I went and took the prisoner in charge about one o'clock, or near one, and took a table-knife out of his hand - I did not perceive any marks of blood on it.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you take him? A. On the first floor of his father's house - he had some breadin one hand, and the knife in the other; the knife might be in his hand for the purpose of eating his supper.

JOHN ROBSON
. I am a Policeman. About a quarter-past twelve o'clock in the morning of the 30th of January, I saw the prisoner, and persuaded him to go home - his mother was there, and his father might be there, but I did not see him; he had no knife in his hand then - he was a little in liquor, but not drunk; I saw him home, and about a quarter of an hour afterwards I saw him going along about half double, into a green-grocer's shop; I could not conceive what made him go in that way - I had no reason to suppose any mischief had been done to Shannon before I saw him home the first time; when I saw him going into the green-grocer's, the landlord shoved him out of the shop - as he came up he held the knife up to me, and said, "This is the knife," holding it out to me - it was a pocket-knife; I took it out of his hand - I did not see any blood on it; I put it into my pocket, and said, "Come away home;" he used a vulgar expression, and said, "The b - r was going to murder me, but I have murdered him;" I took him about half-way home again, and in about ten minutes three of my brother officers came up with Flannigan- I took them to the prisoner's house, and took him; I cannot tell at what time Shannon received his injury - the prisoner was apprehended about five minutes past one o'clock.
JOHN FLANNIGAN. I went to apprehend the prisoner about an hour after the transaction, to the best of my knowledge.

GEORGE HAYWARD
. I am a student at the London-hospital. I saw Shannon on the Sunday, and found a wound on the back part of his leg; there is every reason to expect he will have the use of his leg again, and that he will not be disabled, except by lameness, for a short time; it is not a serious wound, nor in a dangerous part at all, even if it had extended farther than it did - it was about half an inch deep, and near an inch and a half long.

JAMES MORGAN
. I am a Policeman. I should think that it must be a quarter or twenty minutes before one o'clock when Shannon met with this accident - I sent a party of men to disperse a party who were kicking up a row, soon after twelve; I was not present when Shannon was wounded - I saw Barrett come out of Anchor and Hope-alley, swearing murder, but what he meant I do not know; Shannon was brought to the station rather before one - I sent him to the doctor's instantly; I cannot say how long before he had been wounded; I had seen the prisoner twenty minutes or half an hour before that; about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour before Shannon was brought in, I saw the prisoner coming out of the passage where he lives, with a knife in his hand - he appeared in a passion, and used the word Murder! with an oath.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the row you saw at the Rose and Crown? A. Very near to it; there were ten or fifteen persons there the first time I saw them - that was twenty minutes or half an hour before Shannon was brought in.

JOHN FLANNINGAN
re-examined. As soon as Shannon met with the injury, he was taken home, and in about ten minutes I took him to the station - he was not taken to the doctor's first.

Prisoner's Defence. My father sent me out for half a gallon of beer for supper; a gentleman gave me a shilling to get it - I had a piece of bread and meat in my hand; I met Shannon, Flannigan, and a man named Wilkes at the top of the alley - they said, "Here comes the b - r," and ran after me; I ran along - I came back, and caught hold of a post; they caught hold of me; I got away - they caught me, put me against a door, and threw me down; Flannigan jumped on me, also Shannon and Wilkes - I called Murder! they tried to choke me; I still called Murder! Cotter came - my belly was burst I thought; Maloney came, and after Cotter opened his door, I crept into his house on my hands and face - I got just by the door; Flannigan and Shannon pulled me out by the legs, with my face and hands on the ground, into the middle of the road.

MICHAEL COTTER
. I keep a green-grocer's shop. On the night in question I heard a row in the street; I heard the prisoner call out to me for protection before I saw him - I went as far as the door, and saw him; Flannigan came up, caught hold of him by the throat, and threw him down right facing my door; he made an attempt to get up, and Flannigan kicked him on the hip - I went and caught hold of Flannigan; another man came up named Quirk (I think) and made an attempt to kick him, but whether he hit or missed I do not know, and the third man who came up was Shannon; he laid over him, and I having hold of Flannigan, my hat fell off; a man named Maloney, who had been in my shop, came over to me, and lifted Shannon off the prisoner - what the prisoner might have done to Shannon I cannot tell - I said, "Barrett, come into my house;" he said, "My belly is broken, I cannot go" - this was between twelve and one o'clock.

PATRICK MALONEY
. On the night this happened I was just outside Cutter's door - Barrett ran up the footpath along the street as hard as he could, and asked Cotter to let him search his place; a man named Flannigan came up, and caught him by the collar; he jostled him down, made a hit at him when he was down, and I believe a kick too - Quirk came up, and made a kick at him while he was down; Shannon came up in a little time; I saved the prisoner as well as I could - I turned back on Shannon, and stopped him from meddling with him; I afterwards found Shannon had received a hurt on his leg - there was no appearance of his being wounded when I first saw him - I assisted in taking him to the doctor's about half an hour after.

COURT. Q. Did you help to take Shannon home? A. I took him on my back from the watch-house to the doctor's - I have no reason to suppose he was hurt till after he followed the prisoner to Cotter's; he was about three perches behind the others - I did not notice that he was lame.
Q. You must have noticed if he was lame at that time? A. I dare say I might - he could hardly walk when at the watch-house.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

636.
GUSTAVIUS ADOLPHUS FREDERICK ELLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of November
, 1 clock, value 5l., and 1 hat, value 10s., the goods of
Richard Kirkman Lane
, in his dwelling-house ; and
CHARLES GAST
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the said clock, well knowing it to have been stolen .

RICHARD KIRKMAN LANE
. I live in Argyle-street
, and am a solicitor . I saw my clock safe in my clerk's office about six o'clock in the afternoon of the 27th of November - I went out, and missed it on my return at eight; I saw it at Marlborough-street-office lately, and was satisfied it was mine - I had had it about two years; I believe it to be worth 5l.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What parish is your house in? A. St. James ', Westminster - I do not know the direct way of describing the parish.

MATILDA MOORE
. I am servant to Mr. Lane. On the 27th of November, at nearer eight then seven o'clock, there was a knock at the door; I opened it, and saw a tall man, who asked if Mr. Lane was at home; I said he was not, and asked if he would leave his name, or any message, and I would deliver it as soon as he came in - he said there was no occasion for that, if I would allow him to write a letter in the office; I said Certainly - he went into the office; the clock then stood on the mantel-piece; I gave him half a sheet of paper, which he asked for; he then asked if I would allow him to bring a friend in; I said Certainly - he went and let his friend in, and left him on the mat in the passage; the tall man walked into the passage, and I also - I asked his friend to walk into the office, but he made no answer; I asked him again; he walked in - I shut the office door too, and went to acquaint mistress that such persons were there - my mistress had just come down stairs, and was in the back office; I merely told her; she said "Very well" - I shut mistress' door, went into the back hall, and was going down stairs, when mistress told me the gentlemen were gone; I then went into the passage, found the street door open, and looked into the office - they were gone, and the clock also - I saw Ellis at the office on the 7th of this month; he is the man; he is a very tall man - I saw him at the office, and know him to be one of them; I cannot be mistaken about him - I do not recollect the person of the other man who was with him, but am positive it was not Gast; it was a shorter, stouter man, dressed like a baker - I was as certain of Ellis at the office as I am now; I saw the clock there, and was sure of it; I went into the office in a short time in the course of that evening, and found master's hat was taken off the table -I have not seen that since; Ellis had left his own hat behind; I am sure it was his, because the other man's was all over flour.

Cross-examined. Q. How many times were you before the Justice on this business? A. Three times - Ellis was present on the first occasion; I did not state then that I did not know Ellis - I was asked three times, once by a person near, whether I could identify both the prisoners; I said only the tall one - the person said, "I think you can, look at them again;" I said; "No, only the tall one;" it was my master's clerk who said this - I did not hesitate at identifying Ellis.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I am an officer of Marlborough-street. I had been to Gast's house, and went into his bedroom with him, to clean himself, and saw a clock standing on the drawers, on Saturday, the 5th of February - Ellis was at that time in custody on other charges; I said nothing to Gast at this time about the clock - I went with Goddard to Tottenham-court-road, leaving Schofield in care of Gast: when we returned he was in the parlour - he keeps a muffin shop in Hanway-street
; I took him up stairs, and requested him to unlock the door, which was locked, and I believe, the key was in it - he unlocked it; I went, laid my hand on the clock, which was on the drawers, and said, "Now, this clock, whose is it?" he said that clock was his wife's before he married her - he repeated that two or three times over; I said, "Well at all events I shall take it, and you must account for it before the Magistrate;" the clock was identified by Mr. Lane and Moore.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was any body present when you had the conversation with Ellis about the clock? A. No - Schofield was down stairs; I saw Gast's wife - he keeps the muffin-shop; it is a small shop, but does a very great business.

BENJAMIN SCHOFIELD
. I am an officer. I went to Gast's house, after Ellis was taken, with Ballard and Goddard - I went into the first floor room on the left-hand; it is a bed-room - I saw the clock; I did not see Gast in that room - when Gast was in custody (after Ballard had left the house) he came to me in a side room, where I was waiting to prevent his going out; I then said it was a bad job, he having so respectable a business - I named several things which had been removed from his bed-room by Goddard; I named the clock slightly, but we had not removed that - he merely stated that he knew nothing that was brought into the house, it was all his wife's friends, and his wife's sister had brought the property in; I had not particularly noticed the clock to him then, as I then believed it was his own - after the examination I saw him in the passage of the office, and asked how he accounted for the clock being in his bed-room; I made no threat or promise to him at any time - there was only one clock there; he said that was his wife's, and that she had it before he married her.
JURY. Q. Was any body else in the passage when he said this? A. It was crowded - I am not aware that any body is here.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You questioned him in the passage? A. Yes - any body by must have heard it; Gast's shop has been carried on for a number of years - he pointed out a woman there as his wife; I am informed Ellis is related to him by marriage, and had an apartment in his house - I have frequently seen him go there; Moore gave me a hat on the 10th of February - I have had it ever since.

MATILDA MOORE
. The hat has been kept in a cupboard in our house ever since, till I gave it to Schofield-I never saw it in our office till master's was taken; that has not been found - I dusted this clock every morning, and know it.
MR. LANE. This is my clock, I am certain - it cost me eight guineas.

Ellis' Defence. I purchased the clock on a Saturday evening, about eleven o'clock - a young man named
Charles Ross
, came and said he had a clock to sell; I went with him to look at it - he wanted 5l.; I said I would send my aunt, Mrs. Taylor, to see it, she having been abroker was a judge of such things - she went and bought it; it was brought home to my lodgings, in Hanway-street, and there it has been ever since; at my first examination the first witness could not positively swear to me, which I have witnesses to prove - Mr. Harmer, my solicitor, was in the office at the time; I was yesterday convicted of stealing Mr. Chambers' property, and I actually paid 40l. odd out of my pocket for it.

Gast's Defence. I solemnly declare I never had a conversation with Schofield about the clock - I solemnly declare I never had any conversation with him at all; I married Ellis' mother, a widow with four children, and have worked night and day to bring them up - I put Ellis into business: he failed, and from the affection I had for his mother, I took him into my service, not knowing the company he kept - he could work at the stove while I was in the bakehouse, and what was transacted in the shop while I was in the bakehouse, I was not aware of.
The same written Defence was read as on the prisoners' former trial, page 232.

THOMAS PRICE
. I am a hatter, and live in Tottenham-court-road. I was at the office when Moore was examined at Marlborough-street - I attended all the three examinations; I heard her at the first examination asked if she could identify Ellis - she could not; she said so - she was asked by the Magistrate if she could identify any of the prisoners; Ellis was in front of the bar - she looked at them, and had full time to do so; she said she could not identify any of the prisoners - all she know was, that one of the men who came to the house was a dark man, a very dark man; Ellis did not try to screen himself from view, far from it - I was at the second examination; she identified him then - the first examination was on Tuesday; I rather think about the 8th - the second was on Thursday or Friday; she identified him then - he was dressed precisely the same as before; I am a house-keeper.

COURT. Q. How long have you been acquainted with Ellis? A. I was not acquainted with him further than his living at his father-in-law's; I have seen him pass and repass my house, that is all - I went there on Gast's account: a friend of Gast's called on me on Tuesday morning, and I went.

Q. Will you swear Gast was under examination on the 8th? A. Gast was among the prisoners at the bar then; I heard this brought forward about the clock, and attended the next examination; the examination on the 8th was about the clock - on Tuesday Mr. Lane came forward, he said he had lost a clock, and the servant identified it: she swore particularly to Ellis at the second examination, which she did not do on the first - I thought it something peculiar; the second examination was in the Magistrate's private room; I was sitting behind Mr. Harmer, the solicitor, and he was astonished to hear her turn round and say, "That is the man that came to the door, and asked me if Mr. Lane was at home;" Hr. Harmer immediately stood up, and said to Mr. Conant, "That woman before denied knowing any of the prisoners," and she said she did not - I said to Mr. Harmer, "Why, I was present, the Court was cleared for her to look at the prisoners, and she went forward to them and said, 'I cannot identify any of the prisoners, all I know is one was a very dark man.'"

Q. Then she never mentioned a tall man? A. She did not - I am quite sure she never described the man as a tall man at the first examination; she did at the second, and swore positively to Ellis - she said positively at the first examination that she could not identify either of the men; there were fourteen persons at the bar then, and there were two short men who appeared to creep behind the rest, that they might not be observed; but Ellis and Gast remained in front - I have not heard what she has said here; I was not subpoenaed here - I am a hatter: I came at the request of Gast's and Ellis' friends - I told Mr. Harmer I had heard her say that she could not identify either of the prisoners, and he said he hoped I would attend at the Old Bailey; he was by at the time she said this.

MARY MOORE
re-examined. I was at the office three times; Ellis was there the first time - that was on Monday, the 7th: I saw him again on Tuesday - on the first examination I was asked to stand on the steps to see them closely; I said I could only see the tall man, and could identify no other but the tall man (the prisoner Ellis) -I was not asked by the Magistrate the first day (Monday), if I could identify them; I saw them again on the second examination (Tuesday) - I said I knew Ellis was the man I let in; I did not express a doubt about him - what I said was not taken down the first day, it was on the second; I am quite sure I spoke positively to him, and at the second examination again I said, "That is the man" - Ellis was present, and saw me.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was not the bar cleared that you might attend to the prisoners? A. It was not cleared, to my knowledge; I went to look at the prisoners - I was asked by one of the officers; the Magistrate did not ask me - Mr. Harmer said I had not identified him at the first examination, but it was very wrong.

Q. Did not Mr. Harmer say something to this effect,"That woman could not, on the first examination, identify the man, and now she has done it?" A. To my knowledge he did not say those words - he said something of the kind, and I contradicted him at the time; I swear that I did identify him on the first occasion - the reason I was asked about him at the second examination was, because I was not asked by any Magistrate on the first day - the Magistrate was sitting, but, I believe, at the time there was something else going on - they were talking about other things; I do no not think the Magistrate could hear it - it was not loud enough for him to hear; the prisoners were before him at the time, but they were talking about other things which were stolen, such as medicine-chests - it was Ballard who asked if I could identify the prisoners - I do not remember Plank asking me; I believe master's clerk asked me first - he asked me three different times over; he said, "There is a short man getting behind, was it not him?" I could identify no one but the tall one - he did not ask me three times to identify the tall one; I identified him at once - I remember where Mr. Harmer stood at the first examination, and my cold was so bad he could not hear me; I am sure I contradicted Mr. Harmer when he said I could not identify him at the first examination - I did it openly - I had seen none of them before, to myknowledge; the man had a coloured handkerchief on - a dark looking one; it was not white - he had a common coat on; I might have seen him for about ten minutes - he took his hat off in the office.

DANIEL LINN
. I was formerly in business as a shoe-maker, in Tottenham-court-road - I now live in St. John-street, Clerkenwell, and am out of business. I was examined yesterday to Gast's character - I was not at Marlborough-street on the Monday, but on the Tuesday, and heard Moore asked if she could identify any of the prisoners - the prosecutor's clerk brought the clock up to my righthand, and he was requested to take Moore into the passage that she might see the prisoners brought in, to identify them - they stood at my right-hand, and the answer made was, "No, they warnt them," at the time she went out to see the prisoners walk, I believe Ellis was one - I saw him at the bar; the girl returned and said, "They arn't them that I have seen;" it was then said, "We will have the place cleared; they shall be put to the front, and then you shall go and look;" it was cleared, and the prisoners put to the bar - Ellis and Gast were quite in front, and several women behind; the men were all in front; I think there were five, if not six men - there was nothing to screen Ellis: the officer cleared all the front; she walked up, then walked back, and said, "No, they are not the men;" this was on Tuesday; I was there again on the Friday, at the second examination, when she was asked if she could identify either of them, and she identified the tall one (Ellis) - Mr. Harmer told her she had before said they were not the party; he said so openly - the Magistrate then wanted to mend the evidence, and Mr. Harmer said he had no right so to do.

COURT. Q. What did the girl say to the observation of Mr. Harmer? A. She said she might be mistaken; she did not say she had not mistaken the man, and had said he was the man - she said she might be mistaken; she said three times at the first examination they were not the men, and the clerk stood at her side.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How did you happen to go to the examination? A. Having heard of the circumstance, and Gast being a friend who I highly respected, I went to the examination, as I was going to dine that day in Westbourn-place - I dropped in to render him assistance if he wanted it.

COURT. Q. On your oath, did not the girl, when Mr. Harmer suggested she had not spoken to the man, say that was not true for she had identified him? A. She said, "I might be mistaken" - I positively swear she did not say she had spoken to him - she did not contradict Mr. Harmer- Mr. Harmer rose up, and spoke to her, but I did not hear what she said, more than that she might be mistaken; I will not swear she did not say she had spoken to him, I am sure what I describe took place on Tuesday - I was only there Tuesday and Friday.

Q. Did the Magistrate put the question to her "Did you speak to the man positively the first time?" A. I do not know that I heard a word of that - I was on a chair; the officer said I should break it, and at that moment I got down.

MR.
JAMES HARMER
. I am solicitor for Gast. I attended at Marlborough-street on two occasions - I do not know when it was; I have only come into Court this moment- I was there at what I understood to be the first examination; Moore was taken by the officer in front of the bar, near to where the prisoner stood - she gave a description as to one being a tall young man; she was asked if she could identify either of the prisoners at the bar - she then came close to the Magistrate's table, and gave a short description of the way the clock was stolen.

Q. Was she able, on being shewn the prisoners, personally, to identify any of them? A. Certainly not - Ellis was at the bar and brought prominently forward; I have heard part of the last witness's examination - I was at the second examination; Moore was examined, but I saw her deposition had been previously reduced to writing - it was put into my hands to read, and seeing it stated her to have identified the prisoner (she had not been sworn to the depositions, and I was surprised to find it reduced to writing - Ballard was giving his testimony as to something Gast had said;) on finding this statement in the deposition, I cannot exactly recollect what I said, but I expressed my astonishment that she should have sworn to the prisoner after she had been shewn him at the bar previously, and could not; Ballard gave an explanation how it occurred.

Q. Did she contradict you flatly at the time, and say she had identified him on the former occasion? A. She said she had spoken to him on a former occasion, but did not say it was in the office; it was after the prisoners had been removed from the office by the officers on their way to the lock-up room, she again had an opportunity of seeing them, and spoke to him - I only heard this from the officers themselves.

JURY. Q. Did the girl in your presence ever say she could not identify the prisoner at the bar? A. Certainly - she said she could not speak to any of the prisoners at the bar, at her first examination.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. At that time Ellis was standing in a prominent situation? A. Yes, and I believe the place was cleared for her.

COURT. Q. When you told the Magistrate she could not identify him on a former occasion, did she contradict you and say she had? A. What passed was from the officer, and not from her - I think the Magistrate was not present when I made the remark; she admitted that she had not spoken to him in the Justice room, but the officer in her presence said, "When we were going out of the office she had a better opportunity, and pointed him out;" this passed at the second examination - the examination was not going on before the Magistrate when I observed to her that she had not spoken to him; I had seen her deposition reduced to writing.

MR. LANE re-examined. When Mr. Harmer observed that Moore had not identified Ellis, Moore, in the most vicious manner, denied the assertion of Mr. Harmer - it is no doubt a mistake of Mr. Harmer's, that he made the observation certainly is true, and she in a quick, galarious way, denied it; I was obliged to say, "Matilda, don't speak so quick."

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I asked Moore, at the bar, if she could identify the prisoners - she said she was not certain, but she thought she knew one; I said, "Which one?" and she pointed to Ellis - I said, "Go back again to where I told you to stand before, and make yourself certain; I didnot go out with her, but I saw her afterwards, and she said she was certain.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was this at the examination? A. No - there had not been an examination; they were before the Magistrate, but no depositions were taken - there were fourteen prisoners, and there were several charges made against them.

ELLIS -
GUILTY of stealing to the value of 99s. only .

Aged 23. (See page 232.)GAST -
NOT GUILTY .
Second London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

637.
CHARLES NICHOLS
was
indicted for perjury .
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

638.
JOHN JAMES WOODWARD
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, of a certain evil-disposed person, 22 yards of woollen cloth, value 2l., the goods of
George Meadows
and
William Benfield
, well knowing it to have been stolen .

WILLIAM BENFIELD. I am a tailor
, and live in Marylebone-street, Piccadilly, in partnership with
George Meadows
. On Thursday, the 27th of January, at six o'clock in the evening, I saw this cloth safe in our front shop window, which does not open - I missed it about half-past seven; I am certain it was not sold - it was for garments; we seldom sell cloth - it was Shepherd's plaid for making trousers; there were twenty-three yards in one piece, and nine and three-quarters in another - I saw, at Marlborough-street last Friday, thirteen or fourteen yards of one piece, and the other of nine and three-quarters - one piece has a mark where I had cut out a pattern; I found that mark on it precisely the same, and was confident of it being the same cloth - I know nothing of the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. You have only one partner? A. Only one; I employ nobody in the front shop, but have three apprentices in the workshop - the apprentices and workmen pass through the shop; they leave at eight o'clock - I had gone out about half-past six, and left my people in care of the place; when I came home I found a pane of glass broken or cut, and quite out - it had been cracked the day before by accident; the cloth could be got out there - I discovered it the moment I went into the shop; I was the first to discover it - I found my servants still at work; the shop door cannot be opened outside without a key - I had cut the pattern out myself.
COURT. Q. Did the space in this cloth appear the same size as the pattern cut out? A. Precisely so - I have not got the pattern to compare.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I am an officer. On Thursday, the 3rd of February, about noon, I went with Goddard to No. 9, Fullwood's-rents, and found these two pieces of cloth in a room on the first floor; nobody was in the room - a person who lives in the first floor gave me the key; I left Goddard there. On the following morning, between nine and ten o'clock, I went again with Goddard - the prisoner was not there, and we brought the cloth away; I saw the prisoner that afternoon, at Marlborough-street, in custody - Mr. Benfield did not see the cloth till Friday, the 18th; he brought two patterns, and claimed it - it was two pieces of a different pattern.
Cross-examined. Q. Who gave you the key at the house? A. Mrs. Davidson - she went up with us, and I think unlocked the door.

HENRY GODDARD
. I am an officer. On the 3rd of February I went to Fullwood's-rents, with Ballard; Mrs. Davidson opened the room on the first floor - we found the cloth; I waited there till one o'clock in the morning; the prisoner did not come in - I saw him at the office the afternoon of the next day: Mr. Benfield claimed the cloth - on the Tuesday after the Friday, when the prisoner was brought for re-examination, he was sitting in the clerk's-office, but the examination had not commenced; he stated to me that he had bought the cloth of one or two persons who called at his door in Fullwood's-rents, for 1s. a yard, and he could bring a person forward to prove it; he called it stuff for trousers - there was no other stuff for trousers in his room; no owner had been found then - this cloth was not examined about that day.

Cross-examined. Q. Where was he? A. Sitting on a form in the clerk's-office; I mentioned what I had brought from his lodging when he stated this - Schofield was there, but I do not know whether he heard it.

BENJAMIN SCHOFIELD
. I apprehended the prisoner at his lodging, in the first floor front room, in Fullwood's-rents - he was making inquiry about this cloth at the time I went in - I heard him told that two officers had taken it away; he said he could account for it, as he bought it at the door for 1s. a yard: I took him to the office, and heard him make the statement to Goddard - there were a few waste pieces of cloth and remnants about his room; he did not mention the name of who he bought it of.
MR. BENFIELD. I am confident this is my cloth; the piece is cut out here - 2s. 2d. a yard is the wholesale price; I never bought any lower - I have not got the pattern.
Cross-examined. Q. I think you said one piece had a pattern cut out? A. Yes; that is between thirteen and fourteen yards - I cannot swear to the other.

COURT. Q. Had you a similar cloth to the other in your possession? A. Yes, but have no particular mark on it - it was precisely the same sort and length, nine yards and three-quarters - the other was longer when stolen.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought the stuff found in my room of a man who hawks linen about; I was called down by a person who lives in the house, to look at it - as to the gentleman swearing to it by the piece being cut out, I have cut patterns out myself.
MR. BENFIELD. The pattern hole is precisely the same at this end as I left it - I do not find that any other pattern has been cut; I cannot say to whom I gave the pattern.

MARIA DAVIDSON
. I live at No. 9, Fullwood's-rents
- my husband works for Mr. Norris, an upholder, in Holborn. The prisoner lodges at the same house as us, and when out usually leaves his key with me; a man came one day to our door, with a pack at his back, and asked if I would buy the cloth - I said I did not want any thing of the kind; the prisoner being a tailor , I called out, "Mr. Woodward:" he came down - I said, "Here is a man anxiously wishing me to purchase this - can you buy it?" he said to the man, "How much do you want?" the man said 1s. 6d. a yard; I went in doors, and did not troublemy head further; he came in afterwards, and borrowed 2s. 6d. - he took some cloth up with him.
NOT GUILTY . (See page 232.)

639.
HENRY BURDETT GAST
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 2nd of January , of a certain evil-disposed person. 1 writing-case, value 12s., and 1 patent mauifold-writer, value 1l., the goods of
Ralph Wedgwood
, well knowing them to have been stolen .

RALPH WEDGWOOD
. I live in Rathbone-place, Oxford-street, and am a manufacturer of manifold-writers; I keep an open shop . About the end of November or beginning of December I lost a writing-case and manifold-writer out of my shop; I lost a great many, and cannot state when I had seen them last: I know nothing of the prisoner - I saw these two articles again last Tuesday week at the office; I know them to be my manufacture, and am satisfied they had not been sold.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. You have sold many of the same kind, have not you? A. Yes - I should like to see them; I lost twenty or twenty-four that evening, and have seen about eight - part were fitted up ready for sale, and part were not; I never sold them not fitted up.

GEORGE UNDERWOOD
. I am a servant to Mr. Nicholls, a pawnbroker, of No. 43, Gray's Inn-lane. I produce a manifold-writer and writing-case which were pledged on the 11th of January - I did not take it in, but was present, and saw the person who pawned it, and am quite certain the prisoner is the man; he has pawned at our shop for a year and a half at least - I cannot be mistaken in him; he pawned it in the name of Thomas Cooper, Gray's Inn-lane, for 12s.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you seen many of these manifold-writers? A. I have not; it appears to be fitted up complete - I did not hear the prisoner give the name; I knew him by the name of Cooper for eighteen months - he always went by that name at our shop; I know his wife, and always took her to be Mrs. Cooper - I do not know her name before marriage.

HENRY DEMPSEY
. I am a servant to Mr. Griffith, a pawnbroker of Ossulton-street, Somers'-town. I have a writing-case, pawned on the 14th of January, by the prisoner, in the name of John Cooper, No. 10, Drummond-crescent; we had done business with him before; Mr. Wedgwood saw and claimed it at the first examination.
Cross-examined. Q. He pawned it in the name of Cooper? A. Yes, we always knew him by that name: he was in Mr. Griffith's employ about three years ago I understand - there was no concealment.
JURY. Q. Did he go by the name of Cooper at Mr. Griffith's? A. To the best of my knowledge.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner in Little Drummond-street; he and his wife both stood a few paces from the door - we went into the house; it appeared a chandler's shop - we inquired if Gast lived there; a person pointed him out walking down the street - we went after him, and asked him to come back with us and go into his room; he went readily with us, and said he knew what we were come about, that he expected us; we asked what? he said respecting the business of his brother Gast, who has been tried - we asked if he had been pawning any thing? he said he had pawned a writing-case at Griffith's (we had been there before and saw one) - he was asked if he had pawned any other; he said No; we searched him, but found no duplicate - he said he had pawned things for Ellis, and always gave him the money and duplicate, but denied pawning any other writing-case - I do not know that a manifold-writer was mentloned, except as a writing-case; I found a ticket of a manifold-writer in a room in Tottenham-court-road, said to belong to Ellis, and went to Nicholls' - it is called a writing-case on the duplicate.

Cross-examined. Q. You do not know positively that the room belonged to Ellis? A. No, only it has been sworn so here; it was the attic of Mr. Thompson's house - this conversation was a considerable time after the pawning; he might have forgotten it - he was within five yards of his own door; I did not know him, and do not know that he did me - he did not attempt to escape; his brother and Ellis had been taken up - I found nothing at his lodging.

MR. WEDGWOOD. This is a patent manifold-writer, and I am certain was never sold - this case is mine; it was the cover of a manifold-writer, not fitted up for sale -I would not have sold it in this state; it originally had printed directions on it on both sides, but they appear to have marble paper pasted over them, to disguise it.

The prosecutor was cross-examined at very great length as to his means of identifying the property, and finally pointed out several marks in them, and that the case was stamped "Warranted genuine, R. Wedgwood," with a punch, which never went out of his possession.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 23.
Fifth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

640.
WILLIAM PICKARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of January , 1 coat, value 10s., and 1 umbrella, value 2s. , the goods of
William Jones
; to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Confined Three Months , and
Fined 1s.

641.
MARY ANN COLEMAN
was indicted for
stealing 2 shirts, value 4s.; 5 handkerchiefs, value 5s.; 4 pinafores, value 4s.; 2 aprons, value 2s.; 1 jacket, value 4s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 3s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 6d.; 1 cap, value 3d.; 1 collar, value 3d.; 3 pieces of ribbon, value 2s.; 2 bags, value 2s.; 4 pairs of stockings, value 4s.; 4 pairs of gloves, value 3s.; 1 frill, value 6d.; 4 yards of flannel, value 16s.; 5 yards of calico, value 3s.; 1 sheet, value 1s.; 2 books, value 1s.; 1 sponge, value 6d.; 1 scarf, value 5s., and 2 tea-trays, value 1s., the goods of
John Bedwell
, her master ; to which she eaded

GUILTY. Aged 17. -
Judgment Respited
.

642.
DANIEL MENSER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of February , 1 rug, value 1s., the goods of
Robert Sharpe
; 1 hammer, value 1s.; 1 jigger, value 10d.; 1 pair of boot-irons, value 1s.; 1 fore-part iron, value 4d.; 1 seat iron, value 2d.; 1 stick, value 1 1/2d.; 2 awls, value 1d., and 1 shirt, value 6d., the goods of
John Bridges
; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .
Confined Four Months .

643.
GEORGE HILLIARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of February , 1 pair of scales, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Isabella Jones
, widow .

JAMES KENNERLY
. On the evening of the 1st of February I was in High-street, St. Giles', and saw the prisoner, in company with another person - I followed the prisoner, who was going my way; I met Betraun - we followed the prisoner and the other on to Holborn, and from there on to Great Warner-street, Clerkenwell
; I there saw his companion push open the door of the shop No. 9 - he came out again immediately, and joined the prisoner, who was close by him when he went in - they then both ran off. I followed them, and laid hold of both of them; but the other got away; I kept the prisoner till Betraun came up.

ANGELIOUS BETRAUN
. On the evening of the 1st of February I joined Kennerly in High-street, St. Giles' - we followed them to Great Warner-street; I received the prisoner from Kennerly, and in his jacket pocket I found these scales.

ANN HUNT
. I am the daughter of Isabella Jones, a widow, who keeps a shop at No. 9, Great Warner-street. These scales are hers - I used them about three minutes before they were missed.
Prisoner's Defence. The other boy took them, and I did not know of it - he saw them coming, and tried to shove them into my pocket.

JAMES KENNERLY
. He said so at the time, but I did not see it.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Six Months .

644.
JOSIAH RANDALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of January , 1 saw, value 8s. , the goods of
Emanuel Coward
.

EMANUEL COWARD
. I am a carpenter , and live in Gray's Inn-lane. I was at work at Messrs. Child and Vickers, the distillers, in Stone-street, Borough
. On the 31st of January I left my tools in a basket in the stable there - I went again about a quarter before one o'clock, and missed a saw out of my tools; I made inquiry, but could not find it.

THOMAS COWARD
. I am the prosecutor's father - I have known the prisoner twenty years or nearly so. In consequence of information, I went after him, and found him near the Crown, in Holywell-lane - I told him he had been taking a saw from Child and Vicker's distillery - he denied it; I said, "You have pawned it, give me the duplicate;" I went with him to his lodging, and after some conversation, he gave me the duplicate.

WILLIAM CLARK
. I am shopman to Mr. Attenborough, a pawnbroker, in Crown-street. On the 31st of January, about dinner time, this saw was pawned by the prisoner; I lent him 2s. 6d. on it, and gave this duplicate.

THOMAS WHITTLE
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 46. -
Confined One Year .

645.
JOHN HART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 1 pair of boots, value 8s. 6d. , the goods of
Ephraim Wigginton
.

MARY WIGGINTON. I am the wife of
Ephraim Wigginton
- we live in Old-street
, and keep a shoe warehouse . On the 12th of February I saw the prisoner at our shop; he looked at a pair of boots and a pair of shoes also - he desired me to put up the shoes in the window; while I was doing that he ran out - I looked, and missed the boots immediately; in consequence of information I went on the following morning to Ironmonger-row, where I saw him at work; I knew him to be the man, and I asked him for the money for the boots which he took away on the Saturday; he said he was not looking at boots, he was looking at shoes - I said he had taken away the boots which he had on: I knew they were the boots which had been in my window - he said he had bought them in Gravel-lane; he first said at a house, and then he said of a man - I got an officer, and he was taken - I know the boots by a mark inside them.
Prisoner. She said I wore fustian trousers. Witness. No, it was dark - I said I was not sure whether he had the same trousers on then which he had before.

WILLIAM BELSHAM
. I am in the prosecutor's service. I know these boots - I had been in the habit of cleaning them; I saw the prisoner in the shop when I was sent out, and when I came back he was gone - I saw him when he was taken, and knew him to be the same man.

HENRY PERRY
. I am a Police-constable. The prisoner was brought to our station with these boots on his feet - he said he had bought them of a man of the name of Callaghan, who worked at Curtis' bacon yard over the water, for 8s. 6d. on the Saturday evening.

JOHN CALLAGHAN
. I am a labourer at Mr. Curtis' bacon yard, in Holland-street. I never sold a pair of boots to the prisoner, or lent him or gave him any - I have known him some time; he brought a pair of boots to my house on the Saturday before he was apprehended, and said he bought them in Ironmonger-row - I do not know whether these are them.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not buy them nor steal them - I went in to buy a pair of boots; I was drunk, and did not know what I did.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Three Months .

646.
JOSEPH MOORE
and
BENJAMIN JENNINGS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of January , 18 bushels of soot, value 15s. , the goods of
Thomas Spearing
.

THOMAS SPEARING
. I live in Broomyard-alley, Longalley
. I was called out of my bed between three and four o'clock - I went to my shed, found the door open, and the lock and staple had been drawn; I missed a quantity of soot which had been loose about the shed - I stated it as ten sacks at first, but that was not correct; I suppose six sacks were gone - I went to No. 10, Cock-alley, and found the prisoners there; some soot was on the floor of the room they were in - I called for a basin of water to try whether it was my property or not, and it was; because there was saw dust mixed with it as there had been with the soot at my shed - we cannot help taking up the ashes of whatever there is mixed with the soot, and this was saw dust of mahogany - I compared it with that at my shed, and found it was the same - it is very common in the trade to mix saw-dust with soot.

ROGER RAGAN
. I am a Police-constable. On the 22nd of January I was in Long-alley at two o'clock in the morning, and saw the two prisoners coming along with two sacks of soot; I questioned them as to where they got it - they said where they had been at work, at the London tavern; I said, "I can't believe you - I think you would not be at the London tavern at this time in the morning;" they said if I was not satisfied I might go with them, and I went to No. 10, Cock-alley, where they shot the soot out on the floor of an empty room - I asked if they occupied that room; they said they did, but one of the witnesses came down, and said, "Good God! what brought you here at this time in the morning?" I asked if they lived there, and she said No- they then said they had taken it of the landlady the day before; I gave an alarm, and
Stephen Renew
came up - I left him in charge of the property, and took Moore to the station-house - in going along he told me it was his own property; I could not see Jennings at the time I took Moore, for he had got up the chimney - I brought Moore back from the station-house to the room, and then I found Jennings there - that was half an hour afterwards, or rather more.

STEPHEN RENEW
. I live at No. 15, Great George-street, Mile-end, and am a watchman. Ragan called me into the house in Cock-alley; I saw Moore there, but I did not then see Jennings: after Moore had been taken to the station I saw some mortar fall down the chimney - a boy named Onion came in; I told him to look up the chimney - Jennings then came down; Moore was afterwards brought back, and then both the prisoners were taken.
Jennings. I was not up the chimney - I sat on the stove.

SAMUEL ONION
. I went in, and looked up the chimney - I saw Jennings there; I had known him before - he went by the name of Ben Matthews; I said, "I know who it is - it is
Ben Matthews
- you may as well come down;" he made no answer: I found some shoes in the yard where Spearing's shed is, but I do not know of either of the prisoners wearing them.

ROSANNA KEMP
. I live at No. 10, Cock-alley, Nortonfalgate. I heard a noise about two o'clock in the morning - I went down, and saw the officer, the two prisoners, and a quantity of soot in a room; I had seen them there, but they had not lived there.

JOHN BURNESS
. I live at No. 2, Cock-alley. About half-past three o'clock that morning I went to No. 10 - I saw Renew there, and a quantity of soot; the officer afterwards brought Moore in; I got a lantern, and tracked some soot about a hundred yards from No. 10, Cock-alley, to about forty yards from the prosecutor's shed - the track ceased in Long-alley; I suppose the sacks had been opened there - there was no track at the door of Spearing's shed; the track ceased very near Smith's-buildings - I traced it through the passage of a double house, No. 14, both the doors of which were open; I saw the staple and lock were off the shed, and there was nothing to prevent a person then from going in - I found a piece of tin, which appeared to have been used as a shovel.

ROGER RAGAN
. I walked through the double house; when I first saw the prisoners they were in Long-alley, and appeared to be coming in a direction from the shed, which Spearing says had been broken - I think they were sixty yards off it.

HENRY WRIGHT
. I am foreman to
Thomas Spearing
. I compared the soot found at Cock-alley with that on my master's premises; I believe it had formed a part of it -I had mixed it for my master; I saw at Cock-alley about seven pecks shot out, and one sack which had not been shot out - it was worth 7 1/2d. a bushel; my master did not miss any sack - the soot might have been mixed by other persons - I did not find near as much soot as was missing from the shed; I suppose there were thirty sacks of soot in the shed.

Jennings. We were doing work for ourselves, and we had been out to try to get a little soot - we put it down against the wall by the London tavern; that was what I told the officer, and that it belonged to me.

JURY to ROGER RAGAN. Q. Did you say you saw two sacks? A. Yes - I went with them to the room; I then took a short turn round my beat and returned - part of the soot had been conveyed away; the sacks appeared full when I first got up to them.
COURT. Q. How long were you absent? A. About five minutes - the prisoners went out, and said they were going to the London tavern for more.
NOT GUILTY .

647.
JOSEPH MOORE
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of January , 36 bushels of soot, value 30s. , the goods of
Susannah Collins
.

SUSANNAH COLLINS. I live at No. 1, Sharp's-alley, and am a widow . I have a shed near Grey Eagle-street
, which was secured by an iron padlock - I went there about eight o'clock in the morning, on the 15th of January, found it had been broken open, and missed about twelve sacks of soot; I found a handkerchief, which I gave to the officer- I had seen my shed safe on the night before; the soot I missed was worth 30s., it is 2s. 6d. a sack - I traced some sooty foot-marks, from Grey Eagle-street to the top of Pearl-street, opposite Fleur-de-lis-court; it was a damp morning, and that was the reason I suppose.

SAMUEL ONION
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Peter Savage, Moore's-alley, Norton-falgate - he is a chimney-sweep. I have known the prisoner these five years; he was in the habit of bringing soot to my master, about six months before he was taken - when he was engaged in shooting the soot, I used to hold his cap, and I used to see a handkerchief in it; I observed it particularly - I noticed a tear in the corner, and three letters on it; I have had it twenty times in my hand - there was a cook-shop at the corner of Moore's-alley, which he used to frequent, and I have seen him use the handkerchief there; I remember on one occasion, we were standing at the corner of Cock-alley, and he had it in his hand - we used to call him by the nickname of Buss, and I said, "Buss, let me look at your handkerchief;" I looked at it, and said, "It is torn at the corner;" he said, "I know it is;" there were three letters on it in a straight line - this is the handkerchief, here is the tear; here are three letters in a straight line, and one below; I had not noticed the one below at that time.
Prisoner. Q. When did I show you the handkerchief? A. I cannot rightly tell; it was about three days before this happened.
JURY. Q. How long before he was apprehended had you seen him shoot any soot? A. About six months - he was not in my master's employ, but he used to buy soot of the prisoner.

JOHN BURNESS
. I am a private watchman. I was at the corner of Fleur-de-lis-court, on the morning of the 15th of January, and saw two sweeps - one had a sack of soot on his back, and the other was following him; they came as if from Grey Eagle-street, which is about one hundred yards from there - I saw them return twice with empty sacks; I saw them afterwards in Blossom-street - Barnard was following them.

BENJAMIN BARNARD
. I saw two men carrying soot - I believe the prisoner was one, but cannot swear it.
NOT GUILTY .

648.
BENJAMIN JENNINGS
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of December , 1 watch, value 2l. , the goods of
John Rose
.

ELIZABETH ROSE
. I am the wife of John Rose - we live in Walter-place, School-house-lane, Ratcliff
; my husband is a waterman . On the 6th of December, I called in the prisoner to sweep the kitchen chimney, about ten o'clock in the morning - my husband's watch was hanging over the chimney; when the prisoner had got the machine about half-way up, he told me to take down the watch, which I did - I put it into a basin on the dresser, and covered it over with a little silk bag; I went up stairs to get some money, and left my little girl in the room, but she went out to see if the machine was up the chimney - I was away about a minute and a half, and when I came down she was out in the yard; the prisoner soon finished the chimney - he made some difficulty about putting the soot into the bag, and I asked if I should hold it; he said No - I paid him 4d., and he went away; I missed the watch in about ten minutes - no one had been in the house but him, from the time I had put it into the basin; I received information, and went to White's-yard, Rosemary-lane, saw the prisoner, caught him by the jacket, and said,"Where is the watch you took from Walter-place, Schoolhouse-yard, where you swept a chimney this morning?" he said, "You had better come and see;" he struggled, got from me, and ran as hard as he could - I value the watch at two guineas; it cost me four - it was as good for me as when I bought it; my daughter is twelve years old, but she is very ill - I am certain no one was in the house but her and the prisoner.

Prisoner. Before she saw me she wanted to swear to another man of the name of Fossett. Witness. No - a Policeman took another person, but I said that was not the man. I was informed he either resorted to, or lived in White's-yard - I went there, he came out of a passage, and I caught him.

DAVID FOSSETT
. I live in Essex-street, Commercial-road. I have known the prisoner a great while - two Policemen came, took me to the office, and the prosecutrix was going to swear to me, till I took her under a gaslight, and said, "My good woman, what are you going to swear to?" I took off my cap, and then she said I was not the man - if I had not spoken to her, she would have sworn to me, and I should have been where the prisoner is now; I never knew any harm of the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

649.
SUSANNAH MANLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of November , 1 sheet, value 2s., and 1 blanket, value 7s. , the goods of
Daniel Kemmish
.

DANIEL KEMMISH
. I am a bellows-maker , and live in Tent-street, St. George's
; the prisoner's husband keeps the house, and she lives there. About the latter end of November my wife missed a blanket off the bed; we had a box in the room, from which the sheet was taken - I do not know when I had seen that; I cannot say that I ever saw it in the box. On the 25th of January the prisoner and her husband quarrelled, and at her husband's instigation I had her taken up - I have since seen a sheet in the possession of Pool, which I know had been on our bed; the prisoner's husband gave me a duplicate, in her presence, which I gave to the officer.

DANIEL KEMMISH
, JUN. I am thirteen years old. I was left at home by my mother one morning, two or three months ago; the prisoner came into the room we live in, and asked me to go to my aunt's to know if she had mixed the bread up - I went, and as I was coming back I met my little brother, whom she had sent out; she then sent me out again for some flour, and said the bread was too wet - my father was out, and my mother was at Tottenham.
Prisoner. That was at a different time altogether; it was a fortnight afterwards - I sent him for the flour as his mother had left the bread running all over the place.

WILLIAM POOL
. I am in the employ of a pawnbroker, in Ratcliff-highway. I have a sheet, pawned on the 30th of November, by the prisoner, in the name of Smith - she was in the habit of pawning at our shop by the name of Smith, New Gravel-lane, which is fifty or sixty yards from Tent-street.

JAMES KENNEDY
. I was called into the house in Tent-street, on the 25th of January; I took the prisoner there - her husband was there, and gave Kemmiah a duplicate; he said that was his property, and the prisoner ought to be punished - Kemmish gave me the duplicate, and I took the prisoner to the watch-house; she there said that Kemmish's wife gave the sheet to her to pawn.

LOUISA KEMMISH
. I know this sheet is my husband's; it was kept in a box under the bed - I missed it on the night I came home from Tottenham; I do not know the day - it was in November or December, I think in December; I had never given the prisoner, or any one else, permission to pawn it; she and her husband live on very bad terms.

COURT. Q. Now, take care what you are saying, it affects the prisoner very much - are you quite sure you had not given her the sheet to pawn? A. Yes; we did owe some rent at that time - her husband has not excused it; we still owe about 12s. 6d.; we have two rooms there - we have never found the blanket; 1s. 6d. was lent on the sheet - when I went into the room to get it out of the box it was gone; I looked well about, and then I went into one of their rooms - I said, "Mrs. Manley, I have lost a sheet;" and she hooted out of another room,"Oh, you will find it again" - but I think she was in liquor; her husband then said, "That is all you get for going into their room when she was ill."
JURY. Q. Were you in the habit of drinking with her? A. No.

COURT. Q. Now, are you quite certain about the sheet? A. I am quite certain, if it were the last word I had to speak, that I never gave her the sheet to pawn - I frequently heard her husband say he could have her transported.

Prisoner. I went to her one morning, and said I had an article in pawn, and I did not know how to get it out; she said, "I have nothing but a sheet;" she brought it to me wrapped up in her shawl, that the children might not see it. Witness. She never pawned any thing of mine, with my knowledge, but a footman, and then I sent my boy with her.

COURT. Q. Do you mean, upon the solemn oath you have taken, to say that you did not deliver that sheet to her to pawn? A. No, my Lord, I did not, if it were the last word I had to speak; that is the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth - her husband came to the window while they were quarrelling, and said, "Mr. Kemmish, if you will fetch an officer I will tell you where your property is."

JURY to DANIEL KEMMISH, SEN. Q. Where did the prisoner's husband produce the duplicate from? A. I was at work at the window and he said to me, "Mr. Kemmish fetch an officer, and I will discover to you your stolen property" I fetched an officer, and when I took him in the yard her husband gave me the duplicate.

COURT. Q. Do you mean that when you fetched the officer you did not know who was the thief? A. No, my Lord; I made all the haste I could, for fear he should alter his mind - he was in a passion with his wife, and I was afraid he would not give me up the duplicate - I did not know he had a duplicate, but he said he would make a discovery to me, and I judged he had one - I knew my wife had sent the footman to pawn; it was pawned to get something for my family to eat - the prisoner offered her service to take it; I never heard from my wife that she gave her the sheet to pawn; I do not believe she did, for she was at Tottenham when it was stolen.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to ask her for rent - she said she had no money; I said I wanted to fetch an article out, and she lent me this sheet - my husband used me ill, and he persuaded her to prosecute me; she had lent me 2s., and we quarrelled about it.
LOUISA KEMMISH. If I was dying at this moment I know nothing of the sheet being pawned, nor did I lend it to her.

- WILKINSON. I live at No. 15, Wood's-buildings, Whitechapel-road. I met the prosecutrix yesterday at the public-house over the way, and she told me she had lent the prisoner the sheet, but was afraid to tell her husband of it - she was so drunk she was obliged to be brought out of the house; I was there six hours with her - she said the money was spent in liquor between them.

MARY MURRAY
. I live in Cromer-street. I heard the prosecutrix say she lent the sheet to the prisoner, but she dare not tell her husband, or he would turn her out of doors - she was not in liquor then, but got very tipsy afterwards.
DANIEL KEMMISH. My wife was not tipsy yesterday; she was not out of my sight at all.

THOMAS MURRAY
. I was waiting at the public-house with my wife yesterday to give the prisoner a character -Mrs. Kemmish came there, and had two glasses of rum and a good many glasses of ale, till she could not stand.

JAMES KENNEDY
. I am the Policeman in this case. Pool came to me yesterday, and told me the prosecutrix was getting tipsy - I told her husband he had better take her away, or he would lose all his expences.

WILLIAM POOL
. She was so drunk yesterday she could hardly stand, and she was so at the office.
DANIEL KEMMISH. My wife was not tipsy.
NOT GUILTY .

650.
WILLIAM MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of a person unknown, from his person .

RICHARD THOMAS
, I live in Titchfield-street, and am an undertaker. On the afternoon of the 13th of February I was crossing from Portland-place
- I saw the prisoner behind a gentleman, and he took a handkerchief from his pocket; a little girl told the gentleman of it - he was stopped, and the handkerchief was thrown down an area; I am quite sure I saw it in the prisoner's hand, and he ran away with it - this is it.
