Prisoner. I was above one hundred yards from the place when I was taken; I had not been out of my own yard ten minutes Witness. I am quite sure I saw him put his hand in the gentleman's pocket, and I ran after him - he ran down Riding-house-lane, and was taken in Titchfield-street - I was not four yards from him when he took it.
JURY. Q. Did you see him throw it down the area? -A. No, a neighbour did.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down Great Titchfield-street, and a gentleman came and took me to an area, where there was a handkerchief - the gentleman would have let me go, but this witness came up and said he saw me pick the pocket.

JOHN COLLISON
. I took the prisoner in Foley-street; a gentleman had him by the collar - he was charged with picking his pocket of this handkerchief, which he delivered to me.
RICHARD THOMAS. This is the handkerchief - I saw it picked up from the area by an opposite neighbour, and the gentleman took it.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Six Months .

651.
GEORGE PARSONS PHELPS
,
DANIEL CLARKE
, and
WILLIAM NELSON
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of January
, 1 pair of trousers, value 14s. , the goods of
Thomas Evans
; and
GEORGE FLANNER
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.

JANE EVANS
. I am the wife of
Thomas Evans
- we live in Pelham-street, Spitalfields
. On the 14th of January I put a pair of trousers out in our yard, at half-past two o'clock - I went out at four, and saw them safe; there is a wall round our yard, and on the other side of it is Mr. Sykes' timber-yard; I missed the trousers at a quarter-past four.

ALFRED MILES
. I am the son of
Ann Miles
- we live in Hunt-street, Mile-end New-town. On the 14th of January, about four o'clock, I was in Mr. Sykes' timber-yard, playing with some boys; the three boy
s at the barcame into that yard, and said they would mill us if we did not go out - the boys who were at play with me went out, but I staid: the prisoners were then going to rub dirt in my eyes, but I ran through a house - I then returned to the yard, and saw Phelps and Clarke, but not Nelson - I saw Phelps jump off the wall of Mr. Evans' yard, with something under his jacket; Clarke was standing about six inches from the wall - his face was to the wall, and he appeared to move about; they then went out of the gate together, and went up Montague-street.

THOMAS EVANS. I went, in consequence of some information, to No. 4, George-street, Whitechapel, with the officer; I saw Flanner there - he asked if I had lost any thing; I said Yes, a pair of trousers, on the 14th, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon - he gave a duplicate from his hand to the officer; we then went to the pawnbroker with Flanner, where these trousers were produced, which are those I lost.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Is that all that Flanner said? A. Yes, all he said to me - the officer had been in some time before me; I went to the office with the officer and Flanner - I am quite certain these are my trousers; here is a mark where they are broken out behind, when I went larking at a public-house the first night I had them, and here is a hole at the bottom of the legs.

JAMES HOLEHOUSE
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Whitechapel. I have a pair of trousers, pawned at our shop by Flanner, on the 14th of January, about six o'clock in the evening, for 5s. - I gave him this duplicate, and I have the counterpart of it.
Cross-examined. Q. How far is your house from George-street? A. About three hundred yards - Flanner had before pawned things with us - he gave his right name.

ZACHARIAH BAKER
. I am a Police-officer. I apprehended Nelson, in consequence of some information, in his mother's house - his mother let me in; when I saw him he said, "I did not take the trousers, it was Phelps, and they were sold at Flanner's, in George-yard, for 4s. 6d.;" he said the money had been divided between three of them, and he had been to the theatre in the evening; I took Phelps and Clarke to the station, and on the following morning I went with the prosecutor to Flanner's, in George-street; I rapped several times at the door - Flanner put his head out, and said, "Who is there?" I said, "A friend;" he let me in, and the prosecutor staid in the street for a minute or two; I asked Flanner where the trousers were which he had bought of the three boys; he hesitated, and said they were not in the house - I said, "Have you pawned them?" he said Yes; I said, "Give me the duplicate, and I will get them" - the prosecutor came in while he had the duplicate in his hand; we went to the pawnbroker's - Flanner said when he gave me the duplicate, "There is no occasion for me to come - I have not the money to get them out;" I said, "I can get them without money;" he did not state where he got them.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he at any time tell you where he got them? A. No, not till he got to Worship-street - he was at first admitted as a witness; I was at his door three or four minutes before I got in - I was in plain clothes; he could not tell who I was - there was time for him to have destroyed the duplicate; the prosecutor was at the door two or three minutes after I got in - I have seen Flanner before; he is married, but I do not know his family.

Nelson. I did not tell the Policeman what he has stated - two women at No. 9, Rose-lane, told him that a pair of trousers were brought in there, and Flanner had bought the duplicate. Witness. No, I did not hear that till Flanner stated it at Worship-street.

Phelps. I was not there when they were bargaining for these trousers - I was going along, and a woman called me over, as my father was there intoxicated; I took him home, and did not see Nelson or Clarke till half an hour afterwards, in Rose-lane.
Nelson. The Policeman called me aside, and said, "I will give you 10s. if you will tell me where Flanner lives;" I said, "I don't know, only a woman said he lives in George-street."
ZACHARIAH BAKER. I said nothing of the kind.

Flanner's Defence. I was called on between five and six o'clock in the evening, and a woman asked me to buy a pair of blue trousers; I saw the trousers on the bed - I said, "I don't want them - I have no money;" she then said I might go and pawn them - I said, "I don't like such a thing - I don't know whose they are," but I took and pawned them - I gave her the money: one of the boys went with me - she kept the 4s. 6d., and said the boy might have the halfpence himself - the trousers were not in my house; I have a family of ten motherless children to support.
Flanner received a good character.

PHELPS -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .

CLARKE -
GUILTY . Aged 12.

Confined Seven Days , and
Whipped .
FLANNER - GUILTY. Aged 44.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

NELSON -
NOT GUILTY .

652.
CATHERINE RAGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 half-sovereign , the money of
Thomas Kirby
.

THOMAS KIRBY. I am a seaman , and lodge at the Dundee Arms, in Wapping. On the evening of the 16th of February I saw the prisoner, who asked if I would purchase any oysters - she said she had a large family, and I said I had no objection to buy her some beef-steaks for her family; we went to a shop - I ordered some for her, and was going to pay for them; I had a half-sovereign and some silver in my watch-fob, in a bit of paper - I opened the paper, and some of it fell; the butcher said I had dropped something, and he was confident by the chink of it that it was gold - I begged for a light; the prisoner stooped down, and took up a sixpence, which she was very willing to give me, but she was seen to take up the half-sovereign, and I gave charge of her.

Prisoner. When I first met him in a public-house he made me take a couple of glasses of liquor, which I am not accustomed to; I do not know whether I took it up or not. Witness. I had not been in any public-house with her - she complained of poverty, and said she had nine children; I had made a pretty good voyage, and thought I would relieve her.

WILLIAM SAUNDERS
. I am a butcher, and live in Old Gravel-lane
. The prisoner and the prosecutor came to my shop on the 16th of February, to buy a bit of beef - he was going to pay, and some money fell down on the pavement; the prisoner stooped, and appeared to me to pick up something, and put into her pocket - she stooped again, and picked up a sixpence, which she gave the prosecutor; I thought, by the sound, that a half-sovereign had dropped.

JOHN EASTERBROOK
. I am a Police-serjeant. I was in the inner-room at the watch-house while the prisoner was in the outer room; I went into the outer room, and as I went in the prisoner moved - I heard something fall; I looked, and saw a half-sovereign on the floor, by her feet; I said, "I thought you said you had not had it;" she said she had never seen it, nor touched it - she appeared sober before, but appeared very drunk when I found it.

WILLIAM SAUNDERS
. She appeared sober when I saw her.
Prisoner's Defence. He made me drink four glasses of liquor, and put a pipe into my mouth to smoke, which was found in my pocket - he said he would be better to me than my husband.

THOMAS KIRBY
. It is no such thing - I was not half an hour with her; I was in no house with her, and did not give her any thing to drink.
JURY. Q. Did you ask where she lived? A. No, but she said she had a family - I never saw her before.

RICHARD PARKHURST
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner to the watch-house - I found 3s. 6d. on her; I afterwards heard the half-sovereign fall from her clothes, and saw it picked up.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Confined One Week .

653.
JOSEPH SOUNDY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of January , 1 pair of sheets, value 10s. , the goods of
Charles Thomas
.

ELIZABETH THOMAS
. I am the wife of
Charles Thomas
- we live in Castle-street, Oxford-market
. The prisoner occupied the back room on our second floor, which was let furnished - he was taken into custody on the 22nd of January, and the Policeman came and asked if my room was safe; I then examined, and missed a pair of sheets, which had been on his bed, and had been let with the room.

JOHN COOKE
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Wardour-street. On the 4th of January these sheets were pawned at our shop, and I verily believe the prisoner to be the person who pawned them; they are in the name of William Richardson, lodger, No. 6, Wardour-street, for 7s.
Prisoner. That direction is of your own putting - Witness. No, I asked the question, as I always do.

WILLIAM SIBLEY
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner, and found this duplicate on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I did not do it with any intention to defraud, but to supply a moment of need.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 42. -
Confined Three Months .

654.
CHARLOTTE SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of February , 2 sovereigns and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Wilson
, from his person .

JOHN WILSON. I am a shipwright , and live in John-street, Limehouse-fields. I met the prisoner near Finsbury-square, on the 10th of February; she accosted me, and asked me if I would give her any gin; I gave her some at two different houses; we then went to a house in Winfield-street
- we went into a bed-room; I staid there more than half an hour - I had two sovereigns and one sixpence in my pocket, which I know were safe ten minutes before I went into the room; I observed her put her hand into my right-hand pocket, and I gave her in charge - I was rather fresh with liquor.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where did you meet her? A. At the corner of Finsbury-square - we went to a public-house - I had a glass of gin at two houses, and gave her the same; we then went on towards Spitalfield's church, and she proffered to show me the way - I do not remember what time it was; I do not remember telling her it was too late for me to go home - I do not know who proposed my going with her; she seduced me - I do not remember seeing the landlady; I did not pay for the room, nor give the prisoner any thing, nor send out for more liquor, nor lay down on the bed - I had requested her to let me go home before I went in, but I was rather in liquor and went with her; I kept all my clothes on all the time - I do not remember a sovereign being on the floor, and our having a dispute about it - I had not seen any one else in the house, nor made any bargain; I was standing in the room when the Policeman came in - I had put the candle out with snuffing it, about three minutes before the officer came in - I do not know whether she had laid down; I am married.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a Police-constable. I was on duty near Petticoat-lane - I heard a call for Police, and went to Gun-yard, Petticoat-lane; I found the prosecutor and the prisoner together in the dark, in a lower room - the prosecutor was a good deal the worse for liquor, and the prisoner was worse than him; I took the prisoner - I have one sovereign which I received from Mrs. Francis.

Cross-examined. Q. You say the prisoner was tipsy? A. Yes - they were both so tipsy they hardly knew what they were about; the prisoner was the worst - the landlady brought me a light, but she did not come into the room; the prisoner was so tipsy I had to carry her to the station-house nearly - she behaved very riotous, and bit and struck me; the bed appeared to me as if some one had been lying on it - the prisoner's gown was nearly off, but the prosecutor had his clothes and his hat on - it was between twelve and one o'clock.

SUSANNAH FRANCIS
. I am the wife of
Edward Francis
, a Police-constable; I live at the station-house, in Church-street, Spitalfields. I saw the prisoner the next morning, and searched her - I told her to take her stays off; she put her hand into her bosom, took out two sovereigns, put one of them in her mouth, made a bolt, and swallowed it - she then put the other into her mouth, but I seized the back of her neck and made her put that out; I gave it to the officer.
Cross-examined. Q. She had recovered her senses then? A. Yes.
Prisoner's Defence. It is false - I dropped one sovereign, but I did not swallow one; I picked up the sovereign, but did not know it was the prosecutor's.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for 14 Years .

655.
JOHN TOWERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 waistcoat, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
James Kevill
.

JAMES KEVILL. I live in Lucas-street
; the prisoner was servant to Captain Pearson , and lived in the same house. I saw a waistcoat at the Police-office, which was mine; I had not missed it - it had been in a trunk in my room.

DAVID MOSES
. I am in the employ of my brother, who keeps a slopseller's shop, in High-street, Shadwell. On the 16th of February the prisoner came, and brought a waistcoat in his hat, which he asked me to buy - I asked whose it was? he said his own - he asked 2s. for it, and I gave him 1s. 6d.; I gave the same waistcoat to the prosecutor.

HENRY LEE
. I am a Police-constable. On the 16th of February I took the prisoner, in the Back-road, St, George's in the East - I said, "Don't you live at Mr. Pearson's?" he said Yes - I said, you must go with me; he said he had taken the waistcoat.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I lived with Captain Pearson some months - I was sick, and I took the waistcoat to get some medicine from the hospital; I came from Spanish-town, Jamaica.
GUILTY. Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. , and Discharged.

656.
JOHN WATTS
was
indicted for embezzlement .

THOMAS DAFFURN
. The prisoner was in my employ to do odd jobs , for which he receives 7s. a week from each coachman. On the Wednesday before the 5th of February he was sent out with a cart - he was to remove some furniture; one of my men sent him to the job - I do not know what passed between the man and him; I saw the prisoner when he came back, and received 3s. 6d. from him - he said that was all he could get, but the job came to 5s. 3d.

WILLIAM DAIRY
. On the 2nd of February I told my wife to pay the prisoner 5s. 3d. for three hours and a half, at 1s. 6d. an hour - it was for moving some goods in Mr. Daffurn's van: the prisoner had the management of it -I saw the money paid to him.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Have you a person in your employ named Charles Franklin? A. No-I had sent a person to the yard for the van, but he is not here; I do not know who he delivered the message to.

MR. DAFFURN re-examined. Q. Had the prisoner any permission to attend with the cart? A. Certainly, if a job came in; I had not that day given him authority to go with it - I was not at home; he had a general authority to go with it, and receive money - he had been a regular servant at one time, and has worked there two or three years.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you a person in your employ named Charles Franklin? A. Yes, but he is not here; it would not have required any authority for the prisoner to go with the van.

Prisoner's Defence. Mr. Hancock came to me with a message from Mr. Dairy to remove some goods; I went to do the job on my own account - I met Mr. Franklin, and asked him for a van, which he said I could have; I went, received 5s. of Mr. Dairy, and there was a man with the van who had 3d. - I went home, and paid my master 3s. 6d. for two hours and three-quarters, at 1s. 3d. an hour - I kept the other 1s. 6d. for my trouble.
MR. DAFFURN. If he had asked me to let him do it, I, perhaps, should not have refused him, but he ought to have asked me - he would have received 6d. an hour for the job.
NOT GUILTY .

657.
LEONARD JAMES MITCHELL
and
ELIZABETH MITCHELL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of October , 2 pillows, value 3s.; 1 bolster, value 3s.; 1 piece of patchwork, value 2s., and 1 looking-glass, value 1s. , the goods of
John Crawford
.

JOHN CRAWFORD. The prisoners were lodgers of mine, and passed as brother and sister. I missed this property on the 17th of January - the prisoners had been taken into custody on another charge on the 15th of January; they had lodged with me from the 29th or 30th of October, and the goods had been let them with their lodging.

JAMES SPENCER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a piece of patchwork and a looking-glass, which I took in of a female on the 4th and 5th of November.

WILLIAM BROOKS
. I am a pawnbroker - I live in Bulstrode-street. I have two pillows and a bolster pawned on the 30th of October, for 3s., by the male prisoner - I am sure he is the person; I had seen him before - the prosecutor could not identify them before the Magistrate.

RICHARD HARTLEY WALL
. I am an officer. I took the prisoners on another charge; I found this duplicate in a box in the room which they occupied.
Elizabeth Mitchell. My brother went to Mr. Brooks, and he refused to take some things of him on account of his youth, and then I took them - I have pawned things there, and taken them out again.
WILLIAM BROOKS. Yes, she has, but she did not pawn these things; the male prisoner did, and said they were for his sister.

Elizabeth Mitchell's Defence. I intended to redeem these things - I have stripped myself of every thing to support my brother, whom I have brought up; I could not turn him into the street - I have been three days without food, and always paid my rent.

JOHN CRAWFORD
. They paid the rent, but I believe they pawned my things to do it - her brother was not present when I let her the lodging.

RICHARD HARTLEY WALL
. When I went into the room the bed was stripped, and they were in the greatest distress - there were fifty-four duplicates in the box.
The prisoners received a good character.
E. MITCHELL - GUILTY. Aged 28.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

L.J. MITCHELL .
NOT GUILTY .

658.
HUGH SMITH
was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of February , 1 pair of trousers, value 12s.; 1 coat, value 20s.; 2 shirts, value 6s.; 1 waistcoat, value8s., and 20 pieces of ivory, value 14s. , the goods of
Charles Houlden
.

CHARLES HOULDEN. I live in Rawstorne-street
, and am an ivory-turner - the prisoner was my foreman for about twelve months. On the 14th of February I missed a coat, waistcoat, trousers, and two shirts - I got the officer, who took the prisoner; he denied it, but I told him I had seen the articles - I then went to his lodging, at No. 28, Rawstorne-street; he then delivered up to the officer two shirts, a pair of trousers, and a waistcoat - he then went to another room, unlocked a trunk, and gave out a coat - I know the coat, waistcoat, and trousers are mine, and I believe the shirts are; the officer took some pieces of ivory from a trunk, and some from a drawer in the room.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Had he not been employed by you before this last time? A. Yes - I know part of his family; I believe they are respectable.

JOHN MURPHY
. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner on the 15th of January - I went to his lodgings with him, and the prosecutor followed us there - the prisoner took some things from a drawer; I found these ivory articles in the bottom of the chest of drawers - he then produced this coat from a trunk, and I found some more ivory there.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 23.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Six Months .

659.
JANE ROBINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of January , 6 yards of lawn, value 9s. , the goods of
Thomas Mitchell
.

THOMAS ASHMORE
. I live with Mr.
Thomas Mitchell
. On the 10th of January I was in his shop, and saw the prisoner come in with another female - they asked for some worsted stockings; I turned to get them, and in turning I saw the prisoner take from the counter a piece of lawn, which she put behind her - I accused her of it, and asked where it was; she dropped it behind her, and I picked it up - this is it.

Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. Did you see her drop it? A. Yes, I saw it fall behind her - it had been about one-third of the way on the counter - the other woman went away when the prisoner took the lawn.
Prisoner. It laid near the edge, and I knocked it off in reaching for some handkerchiefs. Witness. I am sure she took it off, and when I spoke to her, she dropped it.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 20.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .

660.
CHARLES ROBSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of January , 2 reams of paper, value 12s. , the goods of
Thomas Elborough
.

ELIZA JONES ELBOROUGH
. I live with my brother, Thomas Elborough, a baker , in Cross-street, Islington
. On the 24th of January, I was in his shop - the prisoner came, and said he had brought some bags which my brother had ordered, and he had left some paper with my brother, which he wanted; I said, "I don't know any thing about the paper, you must wait till my brother returns;" he said he must have the paper, and pointed to a bundle of whitey-brown paper, which was in view at the time - he did not say whether my brother had paid for that paper or not; he remained about half an hour, and said he must have the paper - I still said he must wait for my brother, but he said he must have it, and I at last said,"You must take it, if it is yours," and he took it away; I had seen him frequently before, and know he is the person.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not say I had brought some bags your brother had ordered, and you gave me a quire of paper to make up into pound bags size? A. He took a quire of paper, and cut some out, which he left in the shop.

THOMAS ELBOROUGH. I left my sister in care of the shop - on my return she stated this circumstance; I have bought bags of the prisoner, but he had never left any bundle of paper there, and I had not ordered any bags then.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you order me to bring some bags, and tell me to cut out some bags for you? A. No, not at that time - I have ordered bags.

CHARLES KNOTT
. I am a Police-serjeant. I took the prisoner at lslington, in consequence of information - he said he thought there must be some mistake, and he had no knowledge of this shop; I asked him about all the other baker's shops in lslington, and he knew them all but the prosecutor's.
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Six Weeks .

661.
EDWARD PAYNE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of January , 1 plane, value 10s., the goods of
Robert Fentham
; and 1 plane, value 2s., the goods of
William Richardson
.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Lower-street, Islington. On the evening of the 20th of January, the prisoner brought this plough plane to pawn; I questioned him - he said he was sent to pawn it by a person named Smith, in Paradise-row; I told him to fetch the man - he went away, returned, and said the person was very busy - he could not come that night, and I must give him the plane again; I said the person might come in the morning - I detained the plane; he went away, and did not return.

ROBERT FEATHAM
. I am a carpenter , and live in Brooksby-street, Islington. This plane is mine, and was lost from my shop in Barford-buildings, Liverpool-road
, but in what way I cannot tell.
WILLIAM CARTWRIGHT. I keep a broker's shop. I bought this smoothing plane, on or about the 20th of January, of a boy, who I believe was the prisoner.

WILLIAM RICHARDSON. I am foreman to Mr. Featham. This plane is mine - I did not miss it till I was informed where it was; the prisoner's father works near our premises, and I have seen the prisoner come backwards and forwards very frequently - this plane might have been gone a week before I missed it.

GEORGE HAVILL
. I took the prisoner - he denied the charge at first, but he afterwards said he took the plough plane out of the shop, and there was only one man at work at the time.
GUILTY. Aged 12.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Whipped and Discharged.

662.
ANN PAYNE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February , 7 lbs. weight of pork, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Zachariah Richard Catchpole
.

ZACHARIAH RICHARD CATCHPOLE. I am a cheesemonger , and live in High-street, Shadwell
. On the morning of the 17th of February I saw the prisoner near my shop window - I missed a hand of pork, which I had seen five minutes before; I went after the prisoner, and took her with it under her shawl.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Have you always told the same story? A. Yes; I never said I found it several yards from her - it had not been on the ground when I took it from her, but it dropped from my hand; it had been within my window - I did not hear the Magistrate refuse to commit her.
COURT. Q. Are you sure she had it under her shawl? A. Yes, she had a child in her arms - another woman had been asking the price of some pork.

WILLIAM SHARMAN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and have the pork.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded poverty, and received an excellent character.
GUILTY. Aged 38.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

663.
JOHN BARNES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of January , 1 pair of trousers, value 2s. , the goods of
Hymon Levy
.

HYMON LEVY. I am a slop-seller , in Broad-street, Ratcliff
. I lost these trousers on the 27th of January from my door-post, but I was not at home.

CHARLES LEVY
. I am eleven years old. I was at home, and the trousers were at our door - a great crowd came - a man came, took down the trousers, and ran into the crowd again; I lost sight of him - I saw the prisoner at the office on Saturday, and I know he is the man who took them - I am quite sure he is the person; I ran, and called Stop thief! but he got into the crowd - I saw his face.

SAMUEL WAKELING
. I am a Police-constable. The prisoner is one of the sailors who was in a mob, in the highway - I took him at Ratcliff-cross, and found these trousers on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. We went to go to the Admiralty - many of us were without clothes; I picked up the trousers in the crowd.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .

664.
WILLIAM PATTISON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of February , 1 watch, value 31s.; 2 seals, value 30s., and 2 keys, value 1s., the goods of
Ann Stubbs
, his mistress .

ANN STUBBS
. I live in Peerless-row, City-road
. The prisoner was my errand-boy for two days - he went out with me about ten o'clock in the morning; I sent him back for something, and when I returned, the watch which I had left hanging up, was gone, with the seals and keys, from the back parlour.

EDITH WARWICK
. I am servant to Mrs. Stubbs. I let the prisoner in when he returned, but did not see him take the watch - he went into the back parlour to warm his hands.

JOSEPH WILLIAM CLARK
. I am servant to Mr. Fleming, a pawnbroker, of Farringdon-street. On the 3rd of February this watch and seals were pawned, but I do not know who by.

JOHN BROWN
. I took the prisoner on Friday evening, two days after the robbery, and found the duplicate on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I never had the watch.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

665.
GEORGE NORMAN
and
JOSEPH PORTER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 4 bushels of malt, value 35s. , the goods of
Francis Nash
.
MR. HEATON conducted the prosecution.

JOHN ROVE
. I am clerk to
Francis Nash
, of Pickle Herring-wharf, Tooley-street
. Norman was his carter , and on the 16th of February I directed him to load forty sacks of malt to go to Mr. West's - I saw them loaded and counted them in the waggon; I saw Norman leave the premises with them - Porter was not with him then: thirty-nine of the sacks were marked, "J. Collins," and one" F. Collins."

JOHN AYRES
. I am occasionally employed by Mr. West. On the 16th of February I was at his brewery in John-street; the prisoners came with a waggon, and said they had brought twenty quarters of malt - they left twelve sacks there; Porter brought them all in - I saw him count them, and counted them myself; the empty sacks were put on the waggon, but not tied.

THOMAS YATES
. I am servant to Mr. West, at his brewery, Turner-square, Hoxton. The prisoners came there with a waggon, and said they had brought fourteen quarters of malt - I attended to the delivery; after Porter had brought in six quarters I saw that he had an empty sack doubled up on his shoulder, and a full one on it - when he had shot that I took the empty one, and asked if he had brought two sacks at once - he said his mate had thrown it on his shoulder; after delivering four or five more sacks he took the empty sack, and said he would throw it into the waggon - master came up, and I told him what had occurred; he counted the empty sacks - there were twenty-eight, which was right; I should think an empty sack on his shoulder would be an hindrance to him.
JAMES WILLIAM WEST. I was at Turner-square - I did not measure what was delivered.
NOT GUILTY .

666.
RICHARD MOXAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 84 dozens of fire-works, called crackers, value 28s. , the goods of
Charles Cockett
.

CHARLES COCKETT. I am a bedstead-maker - my wife makes fire-works, at No. 10, Willow-gardens
, but we do not live there - I have known the prisoner ten years, and employed him; I lost these fire-works - he left, and I had him taken.

GEORGE KEMP
. I am a Policeman. I could not find the prisoner till the 14th of February - he had absconded; I got these fire-works from Shoreditch workhouse, and some from Gloucester-court.

FRANCIS DAVIS
. I am cook at Shoreditch workhouse.One Sunday morning, between nine and ten o'clock, the prisoner brought me this parcel - I did not know what it was; I put it up stairs, and afterwards gave it to Kemp, but it had then been opened and some were taken out by the boys.

PAUL PRICE
. I met the prisoner in Kingsland-road - he gave me a parcel to carry to Whitecross-street, and gave me 2d.(Property produced and sworn to.)
NOT GUILTY .

667.
JOSEPH MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 2 sacks, value 4s. , the goods of
John Smith
.

SARAH SMITH
. I am the wife of John Smith, a costermonger . These sacks were taken from our stable at Kentish-town
.

JOHN HOLLAND
. I am a Policeman. I met the prisoner about seven o'clock in the morning, on the 12th of February, with a bag, and asked what was in it - he said rags and bones; I made him turn it out, and he had these two sacks - he said he found one behind a house at Camden-town, he could not tell where - this was three-quarters of a mile from Smith's - I found out the prosecutor; the prisoner then said he had them from there.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character, and pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Six Weeks .

668.
JOHN IRELAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of January , 1 hat, value 16s , the goods of
Jeremiah Spiller
.

JAREMIAH SPILLER. I am a mahogany-polisher , and live in Carnaby-market. On the 23rd of January I was locked out of my lodging, and went to look for one; I saw a great many people at the door of the Crown public-house, Pulteney-street
- I asked for a lodging there; I was returning home; a man in a flannel jacket ran against me, and as he passed me he took off my hat - I was running after him, and another man knocked me down; I should know him again - I went and saw a Policeman.

WILLIAM ELLIS
. I am a Policeman. I was going on duty at half-past six o'clock on Sunday morning, and saw about twenty-five people about the Crown, making a disturbance - I went up to them, and saw the prisoner with this hat just stuck on his head; it did not seem to fit - I took it off, and asked where he got it; he said, "What is that to you?" I asked the maker's name, and the colour of the lining; he said he could not tell - I was taking him to the station; he ran away - another Policeman took him; he was dressed in a flannel jacket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had been all night at a wake - a man came and asked me to buy a hat; I gave him 4s. for it.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .

669.
MARY ANN HARBOUR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of January , 2 half-crowns, 7 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Thomas Smith
, from his person .

THOMAS SMITH. I am carter to a gentleman in the Edgware-road. On the night of the 22nd of January, I went to the Horse and Sack
public-house, between ten and eleven o'clock - I was quite sober; I had two pints of half-and-half there - the prisoner was there; she asked me for beer - I gave her some; she asked for gin, and I told the boy to bring a quartern; she stood by me, and I felt her hand in my trousers pocket; (I had seen her two years ago, but not since) I had 12s. 6d. in my pocket - she pulled it all out; I saw it in her hand -I tried to get it from her, but she threw it down in one corner; I saw two half-crowns and one shilling in her hand - there was a parcel of chaps in the room; I was afraid to look for the money - the people then shoved me about, and I got away as fast as I could; I am certain my money was safe when I went into the house - I never got any of it back; I went out for a Policeman, and when I returned the house was all shut up, and she was gone; I had been away a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes.
JURY. Q. Could you hear any body in the house after you returned? A. No - I knocked, and nobody answered.

THOMAS SHILVER
. I am pot-boy at the Horse and Sack, kept by Mr. Moss. The prisoner came in on this Saturday night, before the prosecutor - he sat in the taproom for a minute, and then stood up by the fire; I saw the prisoner speak to him; he called for a quartern of gin, and gave me half a crown - I gave him the change; the prisoner then put her hand into his pocket, and pulled out the money; the men who had been drinking with her were laughing and talking together, and she dropped all but two half-crowns and one shilling, which she kept in her hand - the prosecutor accused her of the robbery; my master was serving in the bar, and knew nothing of it till morning - the house was cleared because it was twelve o'clock - I believe the prisoner went away with the men; I found no money on the floor - I believe the men picked it up.

Prisoner's Defence. I met him by the Red Lion; he took me to this house, and paid for some fish for me there - I heard some money drop, but do not know where it came from; I got intoxicated, and do not know what became of him.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

670.
WILLIAM GADSEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of February , 1 coat, value 10s. , the goods of
James Gadsen
.

JAMES GADSEN. I live in New Nichol-street, Bethnal-green
, and am a weaver - the prisoner is my son. On the 11th of February he was at home, and next morning I missed my great coat from the front kitchen; I never allowed him to pawn my things - I am obliged to prosecute him, as I can keep nothing.

THOMAS COOMBS
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Church-street, Bethnal-green. I have a coat, pawned on the 13th of February; to the best of my belief by the prisoner.

MORGAN WATKINS
. I am a Policeman. I was called to take the prisoner, and found the duplicate on him.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .
The prisoner has been before convicted.

671.
JAMES EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing,on the 19th of February , 1 spade, value 2s. , the goods of
George Meritt
.

GEORGE MERITT. I am a labourer , and live at Finchley
. On the 19th of February I saw the prisoner at Lord Mansfield's-wood, with some wood; I asked if he wanted a job; he said, Yes - I asked if he could do ditching - he said a little, but he had no spade, nor money to buy one; he came to work on Saturday morning, but it being wet, he was late, and I told him he must come earlier in future - I borrowed a spade, and set him to work - it was breakfast time; he said he had no money nor breakfast - I said, "Well, sixpence is no object - I have a quartern loaf at home, and you shall have half of it;" I went home, returned in twenty minutes, and the spade I had lent him was stuck in the ground, but my spade was gone, and him also - I went and told a Policeman, and he was taken; it was my master's spade, but I am answerable for it.

VALENTINE HARRISON
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner on the same day as I received information; he was at Kentish-town, going towards London, with the spade.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Six Months .

672.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February , 1 coat, value 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Corder
.

ROBERT RUST
. On the 17th of February, between two and three o'clock in the day, I was in Seymour-street, Somers'-town
, and saw the prisoner take this coat off the box of a hackney-coach - the driver was in a house; he put it under his arm, and walked down Southampton-street - I followed, and took him; he dropped it, and I told a boy to take it up.
THOMAS CORDER. I am a hackneyman . This is my coat - I had left it on the box.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

673.
WILLIAM STOCKMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February , 3 pairs of gaiters, value 4s. , the goods of
George Scrooby
.

CHARLES BAGLEY
. I am in the employ of
George Scrooby
, a boot and shoemaker , of Oxford-street
. On the 17th of February, about half-past one o'clock, the prisoner came to the door - he cut the tape on which these gaiters hung, and then put them under his coat; I ran out, and took him walking away with them - they hung on the door-post.
Prisoner's Defence. I was passing, and picked them up.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Three Weeks .

674.
JOHN COWDALL
was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of February , 2 shrubs, value 1s.; 30 wooden staves, value 1s., and 1lb. of glue, value 6d., the goods of
Thomas Pickford
and others, his masters .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM TIBBETTS. I am clerk to
Thomas Pickford
and others. The prisoner was in their employ - I saw him go out on the 16th of February, with a laurel shrub; I said nothing to him, but spoke to the head clerk; and on the prisoner's return, between six and seven o'clock, an officer, who was waiting, took him into custody - I went to his house in City-gardens; the officer asked where the trees were which he took from the wharf - he made no anwer, but went to the cellar, pulled out the two trees, and gave them to the officer; we found these staves in the cellar - he acknowledged taking them.
Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. Did you know the trees? A. No - we had a quantity on the wharf; he has been five or six years in our employ.

JAMES HANDLEY
. I am an officer. I went with Tibbetts - the prisoner produced the property from the cellar.
Cross-examined. Q. What did you say to him? A. I said, "Where did those staves come from?" he said, "I am sorry to say I took them from the wharf."
The prisoner received an excellent character.
GUILTY. Aged 35.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

675.
DENNIS BRYAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of January , 1 watch, value 2l., the goods of
James Sweeting
, from his person .

HENRY CLARK. I am a locksmith. On the evening of the 21st of January, between eleven and twelve o'clock, I saw a young man, who appeared a sailor , in Ratcliff-highway
- I saw the prisoner and two other men watching him - the prisoner was in the middle; he ran out from the others, and took the watch from the sailor - he went on; a private watchman met him, and struggled with him - I saw him drop the watch; the watchman sprang his rattle - a Policeman came up, and he was secured; I went before the Magistrate - the prosecutor attended, and said his name was
James Sweeting
; he is now gone to sea - I am sure I saw the prisoner take it out of his fob.
Prisoner. Q. Did you come up while the watchman had me? A. Yes, I came up immediately.

RICHARD JOHN ROBERTS
. I am a private watchman. I was on duty in Hastings-court, and met the prisoner running from High-street, Shadwell - he stepped aside, and I saw a watch-case in his hand; I seized him - he tussled with me for about two yards, and then dropped the watch - I got him down, and called out, "There is the watch;" I could not get to it myself, and thought some honest person would take it up - I sprang my rattle; a Policeman came and secured him, but the watch was gone; several persons had come up the court.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you say to the prosecutor,"There is your watch, pick it up?" A. It was not there.
The Prisoner put in a written Defence, representing that he was merely running home - declaring his innocence, and stating that Clark was a bad character.

HENRY CLARK
. I came up while they were scuffling, but did not take the watch up - I did not want any thing to do with it.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Life .

676.
JAMES BARKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of December , 1 pair of trousers, value 1l.; 2 waistcoats, value 1l.; 1 pair of boots, value 2s.; 1 hat, value 9s., and 1 handkerchief, value 3s. , the goods of
Hugh Edward Turner
.

HUGH EDWARD TURNER
. I am a brush-maker . On the 28th of December I lodged in Brill-row
, in the same room as the prisoner - I got up at eight o'clock in the morning, leaving the prisoner in bed, and the clothes lockedin my box; I returned at night, and on the Friday found my box broken, and the things gone.

MARY HILL
. On the 28th the prisoner came to me, and asked if I had a lodging - he slept there one night, and went away, leaving an old hat there.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner, on the 10th of January, charged with stealing a pair of shoes from Exmouth-street, but have since found these things in pawn.
MR. CLARK. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of trousers and a waistcoat, pawned in the name of Johnson, Coleman-street - I do not know who by.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Three Months .

677.
JAMES BRADFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February , 1 copper, value 12s. , the goods of
William Read
.
WILLIAM READ. I am a wheelwright , and live in Princes-street, Lisson-grove, I lost this copper from a shed at the wharf - I cannot exactly say when; my apprentice first missed it.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he not say he missed it on the 8th? A. No - he mentioned no day.

RICHARD STRATTEN
. I am apprentice to the prosecutor. The copper was safe at the wharf on the 31st of January - I missed it on the 3rd of February, and found it at Nash's on the 14th.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you ever say you missed it on the 8th? A. No.

JOSEPH NASH
. I am a broker, and dealer in rags and copper. I bought this copper of Mr. Boxall, for 12s. 6d. - Webster came and had it from me: when Read came he had a doubt of it, and I took him to Boxall.

Cross-examined. Q. He had his doubts? A. Yes - he said he could not swear to it himself, but would find a man who could; he said there were three letters on it -Webster cleaned it, but could not find them.

WILLIAM BOXALL
. I sold this copper to Nash for 12s. 6d. - I am a rag-merchant, and sometimes deal in stores; my landlord Arbour brought it to me to sell for him.

THOMAS ARBOUR
. I am a carpenter. I bought this copper from the prisoner, who was a tenant of mine, on the 5th of February - I set 9s. off his rent for it; he said it was his own - I did not ask where it came from.
Cross-examined. Q. Was any body present when he sold it to you? A. Yes, his wife - he told me he had it from a man who owed him money.
WILLIAM READ. I cannot swear to this copper.
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT. THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 24.
Fourth Middesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

678.
ELIZABETH CLARKE
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Wilkins
, on the 19th of February , and stealing 1 gown, value 7s.; 1 frock, value 1s.; 1 quilt, value 1s.; 1 apron, value 4d.; 1 shift, value 3d., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s., his property .

NATHANIEL WILKINS
. I am the son of
Thomas Wilkins
, who lives in Long's-buildings, Whitecross-street
, and is a watchmaker . The prisoner was a stranger there; these things were in a drawer on the first floor - the street. door is kept open for the lodgers; the first floor room was locked, and the key left on the stairs - my mother locked it, as she says, but I do not know that; I stopped the prisoner at the bottom of the stairs, and she dropped the frock on the floor - I did not see it fall; it was found near to where she stood - the other things w0ere found in her apron: my mother claimed them - the prisoner wanted to be let go, to fetch the person who she said had put them into her lap - we did not let her go.

SARAH WILKINS
. I am the witness' mother. This gown and frock were on a press bedstead, by the side of the drawers - the other things were in the drawers; I always lock the door when I go out - I had gone out that morning about a quarter-past ten o'clock; I have no servant - my husband was in the workshop on the second floor; I am sure I locked the door, and left the key on the stairs, where I always put it - it was within reach of any body; I returned at a quarter-past eleven, and found the prisoner in custody - the things had been taken from her.

WILLIAM HOOPER
. I am a constable. I was sent for and took charge of the prisoner - the property laid on the table, and was claimed by Mr. Wilkins, in the prisoner's hearing; the first words the prisoner said to me were "It was not me opened the door - why don't you go after the person who opened it;" I said, "We will search you first, and then go after her;" I only found 1d. on her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 60.
Confined One Year .

679.
CHARLES GAST
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 5th of January , of a certain evil-disposed person, 1 writing-desk, value 3l., the goods of
Peter Wood
, well knowing it to have been stolen .

PETER WOOD. I am a writing-desk manufacturer , and live in Portugal-street, Lincoln's Inn-fields. On the 5th of January I went out at nine o'clock, and left these dressing-cases safe in my shop window, close to the door; I returned about one, and they were gone - I saw them at Marlborough-street office about a month after.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. On the 5th of February I went with a search-warrant to the prisoner's house in Hanway-yard
, and saw this dressing-case standing in the corner of the shop parlour; I went to the house again in about half an hour, and told him in consequence of what I had seen I should take the work-box, as I called it - I think I called it a writing-desk; I went to where I had seen it, and it was gone - I asked where it was; his wife said, "It is here" - I found it moved to the other end of the parlour, on the table: he said it was not his, and that he did not know how it came there - his wife said the same.
NOT GUILTY .

680.
CHARLES GAST
was again indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 3rd of January , 1 pair of boots, value 20s. , the goods of
John Humby
.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. These boots were in the desk, which was locked.
NOT GUILTY .

681.
CHARLES GAST
was again indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 5th of January , 3 yards of velveteen, value 9s. , the goods of
John Clark
.
JOHN CLARK. I am a tailor , and live in Cirencester-place, Marylebone. On the 29th of January I lost eighteen yards of velvet from my shop, and saw it at the office on the 8th of February.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I found this velvet in a drawer in Gast's shop; I never said any thing to the prisoner about it.
NOT GUILTY .

682.
ANN TAYLOR
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 16th of January , 1 medicine-chest, value 2l., the goods of
William Martyn
, well knowing it to have been stolen .

WILLIAM MARTYN. I live in the Quadrant, Regent-street, and am a chemist and druggist . On Sunday, the 16th of January, about nine o'clock in the morning, I missed a medicine-chest from a glass-case opposite my shop door; I think I had seen it the day before - I found it at the office; I know nothing of the prisoner.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I apprehended the prisoner on the 5th of February at Gast's house; I saw her in the shop - I told her I wished to go into her room; she took me up to a second floor room - this medicine-chest stood on the drawers; I put my hand on it, and said, "Is this yours?" she said, "It is mine," and that she had had it a long time; I said, "Where did you get it?" she made some humming and hesitation, which was not an answer, and I took her in charge.
NOT GUILTY .

683.
HARRIET DAVIS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving of a certain evil-disposed person, 1 writing-case, value 16s., and 2 machines for the blind, value 2l., the goods of
Ralph Wedgwood
, well knowing them to have been stolen .

RALPH WEDGWOOD. I live in Rathbone-place. I lost this writing-case, with a number of others, the latter end of November or beginning of December - I afterwards found it at the office - it is my own manufacture; I am quite sure of it; I lost three machines for the blind at the same time - I have seen them all since; I think I must have seen them in the course of the day they were missed.

THOMAS VESPER
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 14th of December the prisoner pawned a machine for the blind for 10s. in the name of Eliza Johnson, No.2, Jeffries-buildings, Westminster; I do not recollect what account she gave - I am certain of her person.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Is it uncommon for people to pawn in a wrong name? A. Not at all.

THOMAS SEAWARD
. I am a journeyman to Mr. Harrison, a pawnbroker, of Tottenham-court-road. I produce a portfolio which I took in pawn from the prisoner, in the name of Mrs. Johnson; I have not taken her Christian name - I knew her so well; she said it had been bought at Dover, and cost 24s.

Cross-examined. Q. You knew her well? A. Yes, by frequenting my shop for some time - she gave her right address, No. 7, John-street; I will not swear she said it was bought at Dover, or that she came from Dover.

JOHN KEMP
. I am in the employ of Mr. Barret, a pawnbroker of Norfolk-street, Middlesex-hospital. I have a machine for the blind which I took in pawn from the prisoner, for 10s., on the 15th of December, in the name of Johnson, of John-street, who I had repeatedly seen before; I asked how she came by it - she said it was her brother's; I knew she lived in John-street, Tottenham-court-road.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it not common for persons to give erroneous accounts to conceal the fact of their raising money? A. Yes; I had seen her frequently at out shop.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. On the 5th of February I was standing between two doors in Gast's house, when the prisoner came in; she put her shoulder against the partition, and called Harry! Harry! to a boy who was in the shop - he saw her, but would not speak to her; she turned round, and saw me standing at a short distance behind; I said, "What is it you want?" she said she only wanted to speak to Harry - I said, "What do you want with him?" she said she had come to fetch a shirt to wash for him, and that she washed for him generally - I took her into the next room, and asked where she lived; she said in Grosvenor-street - I asked which, and after a little hesitation, she said Lower Grosvenor-street; I said "It is impossible that a washerwoman can live in Lower Grosvenor-street, what is the number?" Ellis was in custody in the shop, and desired her to answer no impertinent questions, upon which Ellis was taken away to the office - I said I should not let her go till she satisfied me where she lived - she afterwards said she lived in Colvell-court, which leads out of Charlotte-street; I sent Goddard there with her - in the trunk, at Mr. Thompson's, No. 11, Tottenham-court-road, I found these three duplicates; I went to the pawnbroker's - they relate to these articles.

Cross-examined. Q. Did she know you? A. I am satisfied that she did; but the darkness of the place, and the dirty state she was then in, I did not then know her: Ellis was in custody; I cannot say that he lived in that house; for the room pointed out as his, had neither bed nor bedding in it, nor did he live at Thompson's.

HENRY GODDARD
. I am an officer. I received the prisoner from Ballard, and went with her to Colvell-court, Charlotte-street, to a shop there - I asked the landlady, in her hearing, if she lived there; she said Yes, in the first floor back room - I left her there, and from information I afterwards received, I went again, found her in the act of moving away, and took her in charge; the landlord said at the office that Ellis lodged in Colvell-court with her - I do not know whether she heard it.
Cross-examined. Q. She took you to this place as her residence? A. Ballard sent me there with her.
MR. WEDGWOOD. This machine for the blind I have no hesitation in swearing to; here is another, and this is a manifold-writer, not fitted up - I am positive they are all three mine.

Cross-examined. Q. These are part of a number of articles stolen one night in November? A. Or the beginning of December - I sell a great many; these three happen to be the first that I stamped with a tool which I have - I never sold any with the mark of this tool, and these are not fitted up - the prisoner would not know but it was a perfect article.
Prisoner. I leave my defence to my Counsel.

ANN WINCH
. I live at No. 37, Compton-street, New-street, and am married - the prisoner is my sister. I do not know that she lived with Ellis - I have heard her say that she washed for him, and she washed a shirt of his in my room, in my presence; I know she has often pawned clothes for him, and redeemed them again.
WILLIAM BALLARD. The room the duplicates were found in contained a quantity of stolen property, but nobody slept there.

CHARLES GEORGE THOMPSON
. I live in Tottenham-court-road. I gave Ellis, (who has been convicted.) the use of a room in my house - the officer found the duplicates in that room; I married Ellis' sister - he was a muffin-maker; I knew he was in the habit of attending sales, and purchasing goods; and it was for the purpose of depositing the goods, which I understood he bought, that I let him have the room - I do not know where he slept: I believe he did not sleep at Gast's - I have heard he slept at Colvell-court - if I had wanted to find him in the night, I should have gone to Colvell-court.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Six Months .

684.
CHARLES CHANCERY WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of December , 1 gelding, price 70l. , the property of
William Berry
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 24.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

685.
SARAH WILKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of February , 1 dead fowl, value 3s. , the goods of
John Edwards
.

JOHN EDWARDS. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Crawford-street, Marylebone
. On the afternoon of the 19th of February, between three and four o'clock, I was in my shop - I saw the prisoner take the fowl, and place it under her shawl; she then asked Mrs. Edwards for half a quartern of butter - as soon as I could get by two other people I seized her, opened her shawl, and saw the fowl - she said she hoped I would excuse her this time; I am afraid she was under the effects of liquor.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she had mercly taken up the fowl to enquire the price.
JOHN EDWARDS. The fowl was concealed under her shawl.

GUILTY . Aged 48. -
Confined Three Months .

686.
JOHN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of February , 1 bed, value 25s., and 1 sheet, value 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Rilen
.

THOMAS HARRIS
. I am a Police-constable. On the morning of the 21st of February I was in the carcase of a house in Marylebone
, about a quarter-past eleven o'clock; I saw the prisoner coming from the garden of a cottage near that house with this bed - he fell over some bricks; I said, "You are down;" he said, "I am;" he got up, and went over some vaults with the bed - I followed him across the fields, into Boston-street; I then went up to him, and saw his hands were cut - he said he had cut them in falling down; I asked what he had here; he said, a bed he was going to have emptied for the old woman - I said it was very odd he should come out of the house the back way; I took him to the station - I went to the cottage and found the door open, and the lock of the door was shot - the bedstead was down, and the clothes laid in a heap, just inside the door.

THOMAS RILEN. I have the care of the cottage. I went out at nine o'clock, leaving every thing secure - the back door was fastened with two bolts; I left a chopper in the fire-place - I went out at the front door, and locked it - I came home at twelve, found my back door open, the things strewed about, and the bed and one sheet gone; there was a square of glass out of the kitchen window, and there was the appearance of blood - he had let himself in at the window, and out at the door.

Prisoner's Defence. A man came up to me, and said he would give me 2s. 6d. to carry the bed to Well-street, Oxford-street - I went into the cottage the front way, as far as the back door; the man said, "You may go this way, and I will come after you."
THOMAS HARRIS. He was close to the cottage when I first saw him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Six Months .

687.
GEORGE WATSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of February , 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, and 8 halfpence, the monies of
Robert Smith
, from the person of Jane, his wife
.

JANE SMITH
. I am the wife of
Robert Smith
. On the 21st of February I was with
Jane Harris
, in Richmond-street, Westminster
- there were a number of persons collected, and a black man was playing some tricks with balls; we stopped to look at him, and I saw the prisoner on my right-hand side - I caught his hand in my right pocket; he drew his hand from me - there were two young fellows behind him, and they took what he had in his hand; I kept him till an officer took him - I missed a shilling, a sixpence, and eight halfpence, which had been safe the moment before.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Have you always told the same story about this? A. Yes - I never let the prisoner go; I seized his hand - he drew his hand back, but I still held his arm; I am quite sure I caught his hand in my pocket - I had taken out a halfpenny for the balck man, and before I had time to give it, the prisoner put his hand into my pocket; I was not at all in liquor - it was not the prisoner who proposed to send for an officer; it was not more than twenty minutes before the officer came - he tried to get away, and said if I were not a woman he would strike me, but the mob said, "You shall not strike her."

JANE HARRIS
. I was with Mrs. Smith - I saw her seize the prisoner; I went for the officer.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been with her long? A. Yes, all the morning - she had nothing to drink in my presence; I had been with her from ten o'clock, and this was about ten minutes past one - I saw her take hold of the prisoner's hand, and draw it out of her pocket-hole; he put his hand behind him, and gave something to a dark young man, who made his way through the mob.

GEORGE BUTLER
. I am a Police-constable. I received the prisoner in charge.
Cross-examined. Q. Was the prosecutrix tipsy? A. No; I have heard what she has said - I think she told the samestory at the Police-office; she said she found his hand in her pocket.
Prisoner. Q. Was I not standing with my hands in my pockets, when you came up? A. The prosecutrix had held of your arm.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Three Months .

688.
JOHN REYNOLDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 umbrella, value 3s. , the goods of
Peter Gentle
.

PETER GENTLE. I live in Pitfield-street, Hoxton
, and am an umbrella-maker . On the 16th of February I was at the back of my shop - I heard a string break, and an iron bar jar; I went to the door, and missed an umbrella - I looked out, and saw the prisoner passing the White Horse, next door; he crossed the road, and I saw the umbrella before him - I ran after him, and as he was turning into Charles-square I asked what he was going to do with my umbrella - he made no answer; the umbrella had been within my door - a person could reach it without coming into the shop; it was fastened by a string, which was tied under the ferrule.
JURY. Q. Was there a ticket on it? A. Yes, it is on it now.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was passing - I saw it lay five yards from the door, and took it up.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Three Months .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

689.
RICHARD STEVENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of February , 2 dead fowls, value 3s. 6d. , the goods of
William George
.

WILLIAM GEORGE. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Blandford-street, Manchester-square
. I had two fowls taken off my board on the 21st of February - I did not see them taken.

HENRY MALONE
. I am a Police-constable. I saw the prisoner take these fowls, between one and two o'clock - I followed him, and took him in Fair-street with them.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Three Months .

690.
SARAH LAWSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of February , 1 bed, value 30s.; 2 pillows, value 5s.; 2 blankets, value 2s.; 1 couterpane, value 1s., and 1 quilt, value 1s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Fitzgerald
, widow .

ELIZABETH FITZGERALD. I am a widow, and live in Upper Berkeley-street, Portman-square
- I have known the prisoner two years; I took her in out of charity four months ago, and continued to support her. On the 19th of February I missed these articles when I came home - the prisoner had left me without notice; I did not see her till the Monday morning following, at ten o'clock.

JAMES CONNOLLY
. I am a Police-constable. I looked after the prisoner, and found her at No. 8, Mitcham-street, Paddington - I found this pillow, and several other articles in her room.(Property produced and sworn to)
Prisoner. She has sworn very false - she had not a bed, and her sister gave her 10s. to buy a mattress.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Four Months .

691.
JAMES JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of February , 4 sheets, value 6s., and 3 bags, value 6d. , the goods of
Joseph Powell
.

SARAH POWELL
. I am the wife of Joseph Powell - he lives in Mansell-street, Goodman's-fields; I was in a cart going along Brick-lane
, on the 15th of February, at a quarter before eight o'clock - there was a bag of linen in the cart, which I was bringing from the country to my own house; it contained four sheets and three bags - there was a lad in the cart, but he is not here; a Policeman gave me notice that the property was taken.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Did you see it when you were in Brick-lane? A. No; it was an open cart - it could not have fallen out - I have not promised my witness any thing for her trouble.

CHRISTIANA THOMPSON
. I was in Brick-lane, and saw Mrs. Powell and a lad in the cart; I saw a man, whom I think was the prisoner, following and watching the cart - he went behind the cart, and took out this bundle; he was running away - I had before seen a Police-constable, and given information; he took the prisoner with the bundle.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he run? A. Yes, when we cried Stop thief! he ran, but not so much as two or three hundred yards; I had not had any thing to drink with the prosecutrix.

GEORGE BRIDLE
. I am an officer. This young woman pointed out to me a person following the cart; I saw him running from it with the bundle - I ran to take him; he threw down the bundle, and I collared him - I never lost sight of him; it was a quarter before eight o'clock.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure you saw him with the bundle near the cart? A. Yes; I caught him running - there was no crowd there; it was not dark.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not near the cart; I crossed to speak to a person, and they ran and took me.

GUILTY . - Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

692.
GEORGE HARRIS, alias GEORGE PEET
,
JAMES WATTS
,
RICHARD BAKER
, &
GEORGE CRONEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of February , 1 wooden till, value 1s.; 1 half-crown, and 2s. 6d. in copper , the property of
Henry Thumwood
.

HARRIET ASHKETEL
. On the 21st of February I saw the four prisoners together in Crane-place, Kentish-town, about three o'clock in the afternoon - I am sure I saw them all; they threw a till over a wall, which attracted my notice - I then saw them passing copper and silver among them, which I saw Harris take out of his hat - he gave them all some; I thought it was not right, and told the Policeman - I took the till up myself; I did not know them before, but I can swear to them all.

WILLIAM MORRIS. I am a Police-constable. This witness gave me the till, and gave me notice of this - I saw all the boys playing with halfpence, opposite her house; I took them - I found 8 1/2d. on Watts, and the rest of the money on the others - here is 1s. 6d. in silver, and this copper - I took two first, and the other two after.

HENRY THUMWOOD. I live in Junction-road, Kentish-town
, about a hundred yards from Ashketel's - this is my till; I missed it last Monday afternoon, about two o'clock; it had been drawn out from behind the counter- there was about 4s. or 5s. in it, in halfpence, farthings, sixpences, and shillings; I did not see the prisoners near there.
Harris' Defence. Baker asked me to go with him to his father - we went, and he asked these two boys the nearest way to Highgate, and then the Policeman took them.
Baker's Defence. We asked these two boys the way; the Policeman took them, then called us, and took us.
Watts' Defence. I was going after a place, and was talking to these boys.

HARRIS -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

WATTS -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

BAKER -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

CRONEY -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

693.
LETITIA IZZARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of February , 7 caps, value 2s.; 1 shirt, value 6d.; 1 frock, value 4d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1d., and 1 towel, value 1d. , the goods of
Joseph Hurst
.

MARTHA HURST
. I am the wife of Joseph Hurst - we live in Belton-street, Long-acre
. I went out on an errand about four o'clock in the afternoon last Saturday; I had left the property stated hanging to dry on the landing, at the top of the house, three stories high - the street door is always open - it is a broker's shop; I returned in about five minutes, and saw the prisoner coming down my own staircase on the the third floor - I asked who she had been to? she made no answer - I looked about, and missed the property; I called after her, and overtook her on the first floor landing - I seized a basket from her hand, with part of my property in it; a witness took two caps from her bosom, and five from her pocket; they were all wet.

RACHAEL PEARSON
. I lodge in the second floor room. I was cleaning the landing, and saw the prisoner with a basket - I took seven caps from her bosom and her pocket - I kept her till the Policeman came.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I unfortunately went up stairs, and the things had fallen, but I did not put them into my basket; I took them up, but did not mean to take them away.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Seven Years .

694.
JAMES HALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February , 1 cap, value 3s., the goods of
Sarah Green
, from the person of
Frederick Gilbert Green
.

ELIZA COLE
. I was in South-street, St. Luke's
, on Thursday last, between three and four o'clock in the afternoon - I saw a little boy with a cap on; the prisoner took it off his head, and ran away - the lamplighter stopped him in my presence, took the cap from him, and gave it to me.

WILLIAM CROCKLEY
. I am a lamplighter. I saw the prisoner running with the cap under his jacket, as I was cleaning a lamp at the corner of South-street - I got down the ladder, and took him in Ropemaker-street; I took the cap, and gave it to Cole.
SARAH GREEN. I am the mother of Frederick Gilbert Green - I am a widow. This is my cap, and my son had it on; the prisoner was brought to my shop, and I gave charge of him.
GUILTY. Aged 13.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutrix .
Confined Three Months .

695.
ANN GOWER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February , 1 handkerchief, value 2d.; 1 purse, value 2d., and 1 sovereign, the property of
Jeremiah McGurrin
, from his person .

JEREMIAH McGURRIN
. I keep a beer and porter shop in Barbican. On the 4th of February I received a sovereign and 2s. 6d. in silver, at Shadwell, in the evening - I then went with two other persons, and had 1 1/2 lb. of steaks, two pots of porter, and three four-penny worths of gin-and-water between us; I then went to another public-house, where I saw the prisoner - she asked me to treat her, which I did; we were there two or three hours - we had about two quarterns of gin, and I had four pennyworth of gin-and-water; I was not drunk - we came together to Red Lion-market, Whitecross-street
; she followed me nearly to my own house - I had not known her before; I had taken out my bag and paid for the liquor at the public-house - I felt in it a sovereign, and 1s. 6d., and I had 6d. worth of copper in the same pocket - when I got near to Red Lion-market I had occasion to stop; I took my bag from my right-hand breeches pocket, and thrust it into my bosom for safety, as I thought the prisoner followed me too long; no sooner had I done that than she snatched the bag from my bosom, and ran away - I sung out Stop thief! she ran out of the market; I made a rush to catch her, and fell on my knees - she ran out, but came into the market again, and the Policeman took her; he found on her my pocket handkerchief, but none of the money, nor the bag - I was sober, and I swear she took it from me; I did not like her being so long about me, and wanted to get from her; I am married.

GEORGE GLADWELL
. I am a Police-constable. I heard the alarm, and saw the prisoner run about twenty yards before I caught her; the prosecutor said she had robbed him of a sovereign, and a bag - the flap of his breeches was undone, and the knees muddy: I found the handkerchief on the prisoner, a sixpence, and 4d. in copper; the prosecutor was the worse for liquor, but not drunk.
JEREMIAH McGURRIN. This handkerchief was in my coat pocket - I did not give it to her.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that the prosecutor, who was intoxicated, had followed her, endeavouring to prevail on her to accompany him, but that she had not robbed him.
GUILTY of stealing the handkerchief . Aged 24.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

696.
JAMES CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of December , 1 coat, value 2l. 10s., and 1 hat, value 10s. , the goods of
Thomas Ellis
.

THOMAS ELLIS. I am a sawyer , and live in Crown-street, Soho
- the prisoner lodged in the same house, and slept with me; he was errand-boy to Mr. Matthews. On the 28th of December I got up first in the morning, and left my coat and hat in the room - I returned at five o'clockin the evening; they were gone, and so was the prisoner -I found him last Wednesday week; I asked him about my coat and hat, and he said he had sold them to a Jew for 10s.

JANE EDWARDS
. I live in the house . The prisoner told me that
Thomas Ellis
had sent him for his coat and hat - that he was at his uncle's, and was tipsy ; he went up stairs , got them , and took them away.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

697.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of February , 1 pair of trousers , value 8s., and 1 waistcoat , value 4s. , the goods of
Frederick Best
.

FREDERICK BEST
. I am groom to Mr. Isaacs , and lodge in Cox-court
- the prisoner lodged there, and slept with me. I got up on the 1st of February , and left my trousers , waistcoat , and the prisoner in the room; I returned at night , but did not miss them till next morning - the prisoner slept there that second night; I spoke to him about them - he said he could answer for himself that he had not had them .

CHARLES WORLEY
. I am a pawnbroker . I have a pair of trousers and a waistcoat , pawned by the prisoner, on the 1st of February .
Prisoner. I have often pawned them for him .

FREDERICK BEST
. I have asked him to pawn them for myself , but not at that time ; he has pawned them , and given me the money .
JURY. Q. Has he ever pawned them for his own accomodation ? A. No, only for me - I have lent him 1s. or 2s. out of it; he had no authority to pawn them .
NOT GUILTY .
The Number of Prisoners committed for Trial at the present Session, was 371.
Of whom were Acquitted or Discharged by Proclamation ..... 121
Convicted ..... 250
Of whom 27 have Received Sentence of Death.
9..... Transportation for Life .
120 carried up .
120 brought up.
115 have been Imprisoned for various terms , Whipped or Fined .
15 Judgments Respited .

"1st
"6 from the top, read thyroid gland .
"1st
